output: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I welcome the approach that we describe in the White Paper, which is to address the causes of malnutrition and obesity and the resulting diseases.
Unfortunately, in food policy in Europe, no matter whether we talk about never profiles, about food labelling or even in some places in the white paper, we fall into a very one-sided approach.
We are trying to solve the problems we have in Europe through product policy.
And I believe that it is fundamentally a wrong political approach to assume that there are good and bad foods.
Viele Änderungsanträge zeigen das, das gibt es nicht.
There are only good and bad or even balanced and unbalanced diets.
Das sollte unser Ansatz sein.
The causes of malnutrition are multifaceted.
To fix it by trying to guide the consumer through product labeling or even with advertising bans or regulations or different value-added tax rates will not lead us to the goal.

I believe everything we do here, I don't want to pre-empt the debate on the labeling ordinance, but everything we do here should be a bit under the heading of what can we do to motivate consumers to think about their eating habits?
A traffic light sign that suggests to him I am now facing a good or bad product is, in my opinion, more of an instrument of deflation than an instrument of education and enlightenment.
Deswegen wünsche ich mir hier einen ausgewogenen Ansatz und die Erkenntnis, dass uns allein der Weg über die Produktpolitik hier nicht weiterbringen wird. Vielen Dank.
President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, the budget control has no new topics.
We are satisfied with the old and would also be satisfied with progress on the old issues.
Five points in the first place our urgent request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in the establishment of the rule of law, the judiciary, and financial control.
We don't want to be where we are today in two years, and that's why this point is very, very important to us.
The second point is the declaration of reliability for the overall budget after the graduated control procedures in consultation with the national audit offices.
It would be nice if we could make decisive progress in the last six months, which is all the Commission has left, or at least agree on a common path.
One is modest as a budget controller.
The third point would be the simplification.
We need to help the lower levels of administration in the Member States more in the implementation of EU law.
It is clear that they are completely overwhelmed by large parts of EU law. This is why the high error rates are also occurring.
The fourth point, the external assistance, here I would like to address above all Kosovo and the question of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Committee on Budgetary Control has been to Kosovo, and I would now like to announce that Kosovo will play a certain role in the reduction of the budget.
I believe that we have far exceeded the possibilities of the European Union so far and that we urgently need to revise this.
The fifth point would be the improvement of cooperation among member states in the fight against fraud.
We have homework here, especially for the ladies and gentlemen of the Council.

The Parliament will vote on the legal basis, the regulation for combating fraud, in November. And then we have to think together how we can continue it if we want to achieve better results in this field.
Das war bis jetzt zumindest unser gemeinsamer Wunsch.
Thank you, Mr. President. India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other on all levels, especially at the level of so-called ordinary people.
Business travelers, tourists, students, and so on. A brief note on this. It also has significance for the Commission's legislative program, which we discussed earlier.
In global air traffic, we need good security regulations, those that make a difference and not just alibi measures.
It would therefore be a sensible, really necessary measure to finally repeal the senseless Liquids regulations and to come up with something better.
I voted for the resolution because it is a clear demand on the Russian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled with the questionable, yes, falsified parliamentary elections of September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of the opposition as well as civil society.

At the same time, we have today asked the Council and Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between the peoples and to democratize the country by seriously considering the possibility of one.
Reduction of visa fees for Belarusian citizens, when considering their entry into the Schengen area, and thus prevent an increasing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
I would like to first defend myself against the spirit of a statement that was heard a few minutes ago, that foreigners would flood our labor market.
And secondly, I would have liked a clearer, more unambiguous report from the Committee on Employment.
Trust in the social cohesion of the European Union can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as a European primary right.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, Commission, Member States and the EGH and not be satisfied with merely demanding a balance between fundamental rights and internal market freedoms and freedoms.
With this, we do not change anything. Social fundamental rights are just like freedom rights, human rights that must not be restricted by the freedoms of the internal market.
And it is about defending and improving the European social model, and the highest time is for the introduction of a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU treaties.
And it is time to change the sending guidelines in such a way that wage and minimum wage requirements are not limited to minimum requirements. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr President, I would like to join in thanking the rapporteur Doris Pack, who has already been rightly praised by many colleagues.
We have with you someone who, hopefully, has not actually shed the blood of the heart, but has invested a lot of heart in this room.
I am pleased with you and the colleagues who have also said that there have been some progress, also in the area of police cooperation.
This is important so that actual life on site can also function within reasonable limits.

I believe, however, that we must repeatedly point out to our interlocutors in Bosnia and Herzegovina that a great deal still needs to be brought in from their own side, perhaps even more than is currently being brought in in some areas.
The internal cooperation, the willingness to this internal cooperation within the ethnic groups, is something that we must constantly demand.
It is not the case that everyone tries to go their own way.
And also the integration into regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is important.
Thank you, Madam President, the distance between the European Union and the citizens must not become as great as it has become.
Wir müssen schauen, dass sie verkleinert wird.
In this context, the Commissioner has an important task to perform, especially when and where he does it well.
It is primarily about us having to expect commitment and discretion from the Commissioner.
It's about not setting too high expectations that no one can meet.

But it is also a matter of ensuring that, wherever there have been complaints in the administration of European bodies, they are addressed and, if possible, reasonable solutions are sought that can then ensure and satisfy the citizens.
The previous practice has shown that the Commissioner takes this task seriously and does it well.
We can hope that this will continue to be the case and thank him and the rapporteur for this report.
"Die Bedeutung der deutschen Sprache für die kulturelle Identität ist unbestreitbar. Sie dient als Vehikel für die Übertragung von Traditionen und Werten von einer Generation zur nächsten."
Dear colleagues, ten years after the implementation of the monetary union, Europe is in a severe crisis.
Banks collapse or are supported by billions from the state budget. The sales collapse and millions of people fear for their jobs and their future.
Aber nicht nur der Markt hat versagt, auch die herrschende Politik scheint unfähig, aus ihren Fehlern zu lernen.

We believe that even with such interjections, they do not want to profile themselves in a special way. We believe that serious mistakes were made in the construction of the Economic and Monetary Union.
Such a mistake is the structural divergence of monetary and fiscal policy. One cannot create a common currency without at the same time harmonizing tax and expenditure policy at least in principle.
I think the economic imbalances in the eurozone have become enormously more severe.
And what we need now is actually better coordination of economic and, above all, tax policy.
We need effective measures against tax dumping. In addition, tax havens must be closed and capital traffic must finally be controlled again.
The second serious mistake we see in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

Whoever considers consolidation of budgets to be essential in times like these is obviously living in another world. Nothing would be more fatal than to respond to this economic crisis with public austerity programs.
The Stability Pact has clearly demonstrated its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our opinion, an investment offensive is necessary to renew public infrastructure and improve the situation of the socially disadvantaged in Europe.
A third mistake, which we see in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is solely committed to the goal of price stability.

We advocate for democratic control of the European Central Bank and we also demand a correction of the monetary policy mandate of the ECB, in which in the future growth and employment must be at least equally promoted with price stability.
The current crisis also offers an opportunity for far-reaching reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This chance should not be squandered lightly.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner, Mr. President-in-Office, ladies and gentlemen, in fact, the automotive industry is in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
Especially the financial crisis has once again forced the crisis in this sector and in the member states, solutions are currently being worked on.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
And that is why we need European solutions to overcome the crisis in this key European industry.
Almost all car companies have European structures.

And to make necessary investments in environmentally friendly cars, which has been mentioned several times here today, in order to be able to promote environmentally friendly and low consumption technologies, car manufacturers need public guarantees or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
But also the supplier industry, that would be very important, must not be forgotten.
Especially in the supplier industry, it is small and medium-sized enterprises where jobs are created and where innovations take place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
During the last plenary session, the Council President made a proposal to protect key industries.
A good proposal, in my opinion, if you think this proposal through to the end, it is called a Volkswagen Act for the entire European automotive industry.
Und dies wäre sicherlich ein gutes Instrument.
But this protective instrument is currently being fought by the European Commission.
And my question to the Commission will the European Commission hold on to this course despite the crisis in the automotive industry, or is it now changing this course in the face of the crisis?
Yes, Mr President, Mr President of the European Court of Auditors, Vice-President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen, it has indeed become a tradition to state.
It is not permissible for a declaration of reliability to be issued repeatedly in the relationship between expenditure at the European level and administration at the national level.

I can remember conversations with the former president of the Court of Auditors, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that, due to the structures, it is not possible at all that a declaration of reliability can be given.
Therefore, we should consider how this instrument can be filled with life so that the goal of a declaration of reliability, if justified, can also be achieved.
And of course, we have to distinguish a few things from each other.
Firstly, a budget that includes around ninety-five percent subsidies is much more susceptible to fraud than a national budget or a regional or municipal budget.

A subsidy budget that is essentially managed by the member states, which have demanded much more independence from us in the new financial period, because the accusation of the last funding period was that too much was being centrally controlled.
This of course also means that the responsibility for the money must be taken over regionally and nationally.
Und n dritten Themenbereich will ich nur kurz ansprechen.
We must also learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
Auch dessen Dinge, die immer gerne zusammengeworfen werden.
I am also annoyed when things are funded with EU money that are not necessarily necessary.
Das war aber nicht Betrug, das war Verschwendung.

And that is why those who have the responsibility for the projects, especially in the field of structural policy, the Member States, also have the responsibility to ensure that money is not wasted and that only the projects that really create added value for the region are promoted.
Therefore, I believe we should also consider converting parts of structural policy to interest-free loans.
If member states have to pay back, then they only promote what they really need. Thank you very much.
It is not only difficult for me to adjust to this emerging self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to the management of the financial market crisis.
Because if Europe, if this EU were a functioning democracy, you would first have to ask the question of responsibility and how all this could have happened.
It is simply not true that all the problems we have now in front of us are a tsunami and what is natural law, but it is made by human hands.
And with all the regulatory zeal that this Union has shown, one wonders why it did not act when, to a remarkable extent, banks began to cross national borders.
Why did they not act despite appropriate warnings when the derivatives had crept in like this?
I remember well that Nobel Prize winner Joseph Stiglitz addressed all these points.
There was silence, there was a taboo.
One should start there, because recognizing one's own mistakes is the key to the solution in the future.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, my question is about what you think if Iceland and Hungary were to introduce the euro as a second currency.
Do you think that this could solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is do you believe that it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which would then be used to strengthen the banks' own capital?
My third question is, do you not believe that a reduction in value-added tax would support imports, especially from China and India?

Wäre es nicht vernünftiger, über Steuerreduzierung für unsere Betriebe nachzudenken und für unsere Arbeitnehmer, dass man Investitionsprämien zahlt, dass man die progressive Abschreibung dementsprechend in

Mittelpunkt stellt und dass man vor allem geringwertige Wirtschaftsgüter um den Faktor 10 erhöht, so dass also nicht Scheingewinne besteuert wird, dass das Geld in den Unternehmungen bleibt und dass damit die Löhne auch besser bezahlt werden.
Thank you, Madam President. The comprehensive report clearly shows how many human rights violations are happening in the world every day.
This is sixty years after the declaration of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, particularly frightening and calls on us to intensify our efforts.
For this reason, I would also like to advocate for the current Subcommittee on Human Rights to be established as the main committee.
Today we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Hu Jintao, who advocates for human rights and the environment in China.
Because he is incarcerated, he could not take it over personally.
Scandal for China and tomorrow there will be a debate on human rights violations in Russia.
In our relations with these two countries, we must not only give economic interests, but above all, human rights, a higher priority.
We demand freedom for Hu Jia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as rapporteur for the Office for the Fight against Fraud, one makes interesting experiences, for example, that everyone talks about combating fraud and no one does anything.
Or the experience that the Member States calculate their payments to the European Union with a fine-toothed comb, but put on their spending pants when it comes to spending this money?
And even make it easy for fraudsters, for example, by the fact that it still takes an average of thirty-six months for irregularities to be reported to the European Union at all.
The European Parliament does not agree with this.
We want an efficient fight against fraud that also includes prevention.
We want the Member States to address the fight against fraud and for us to discuss together the needs and problems of this issue.
We want a greater interest of the national justice authorities in the further pursuit of OLAF mediation results.
There must no longer be free spaces for corruption as there have been in the past.
We need to equalize European money with national money.
We want an independent office that has the necessary resources and legal basis to carry out its tasks.
And we want an office that can work with the member states noiselessly and efficiently.
Our statement on the legal basis one thousand seventy-three ninety-nine anticipates all of these points.
We advocate for the further development of this regulation as a centerpiece of the Office for the Fight Against Fraud, together with the Council.
We call on the Council to take our statement into account. We call on the Council to start the talks on the further development of this regulation.
We want to find a solution to Olaf's problems.
I thank all the factions of the High House that they also support this in a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and the Czech Presidency of the Council to pick up the ball of the Parliament and play it back.
We have also taken up solutions in our proposals that the Council Working Group has developed and introduced.
On our part, I would like to express our interest in a swift conclusion of this regulation and assure you of our constructive willingness to discuss on the basis of our proposals.
A consolidation of all OLAF legal bases, as the Council has envisaged, means a further considerable loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
Olaf is soon celebrating his tenth birthday.
A consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
We take the fight against fraud too seriously.
We want to realize the feasible now in cooperation with the Council.
Thank you very much.
Mr President, I would like to take up a point that my Austrian colleague Mr Rübig made earlier.

We spend less than one percent of the European gross domestic product on Europe, and at the same time we demand that more and more tasks for more and more member states of the European Union be managed.
Diese Rechnung kann sich nicht ausgehen. Es ist daher auch wirklich unglaubwürdig, wenn wir seit vielen Jahren an den Sparkurs fahren, den Sparkurs aber nicht nur in der Sparsamkeit.
Verwendung unserer Gelder einsetzen, sondern im Grunde genommen dazu, dass dann die Finanzminister am Ende des Jahres wieder Geld einstreichen und es zuhause in ihre Budgets einfließen lassen.
We have enough new tasks for which we should spend our money.
We also have tasks that we have not really budgeted for accordingly for years.
I believe that the information funds of the European Union should be significantly increased if we really want to bind European citizens to Europe.
And there are many tasks in the area of students and teacher exchanges that Europe could undertake here.
Also auf dem Justizsektor einen bisher traditionell staatlichen Reservatsbereich voranschreitet.
This corresponds to the changed living conditions of the people in our Union.
But, and this remark has already been made several times, integration should not be too far into traditionally grown and, above all, functioning structures.
Not everything can be beaten with a sledgehammer.
Public records and public records holders are quite differently designed in many Member States.
In Austria, but not only in our country, the notary office has a long tradition and a high level of security and trust.
This should not be put at risk without necessity, just because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Daher Integration und wechselseitige Öffnung ja, aber mit Augenmaß.
Thank you very much, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, pesticides are and remain essential tools of the agricultural industry.
Farmers need a minimum selection of pesticides because it is about protecting the local cultural landscape, high-quality food and the protection of resources.
We often conduct discussions about chemicals on a very irrational level.
To achieve reasonable results, however, we must think and act rationally.
The consequences of the original parliamentary position would have been fatal. A broad ban on plant protection products, thus lower yields in agriculture and, ultimately, rising food prices.
Therefore, I am pleased that a compromise was found in the trilogue negotiations.
It is welcome that we have retained the three-zone regulation, albeit with significant exceptions for the member states.

A bold step towards a consistent internal market solution would look different at this point. In addition to the acceptable compromises, we should not preempt a final definition of endocrine active substances, but actually give the EU Commission the four years to present a scientifically based definition.
Otherwise, we would be violating the precautionary principle at this point.
And finally, I find it regrettable that we do not dare to initiate a follow-up assessment of the agreement that has now been reached. Thank you.
As it was the last time a head of government or head of state came to the corresponding opinion poll, the president of this house intervened massively.
Back then, it was about a matter that was very important to him, namely the Lisbon Treaty.
If today the president, the sovereignly elected president of a country, speaks and is massively interrupted by the socialist side, the president does not object.
Do you know what that is?
This is not democracy, this is arbitrariness, and I demand that appropriate measures be taken.
Kinder und Politik selten gehen die Interessen von Bürgern und Politikern so weit auseinander.
Among the citizens of all of Europe, the issue of children is at the very top of the agenda.
For politicians, children's issues rank lower than distant lives, as we can also see here.
I know of no country in which there is a separate Ministry of Children. There is also no single representative for the interests of our youngest citizens in the Commission.
In parliament, the issue of children is scattered across all committees.
Therefore, I would like to draw the Commission's attention to the fact that it is dealing with childcare facilities and the children in Barcelona today.
Thank you. In our parliamentary working group Quality of Childhood, we have determined the following: Our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here, now and today, is completely uncertain.
A child today can climb all the way up the social ladder or fall all the way down.
It can stay in its own cultural circle or look for a new one.
He can follow a similar life path as his parents or do exactly the opposite.
It can be someone from the other or from the same gender.
All of this was completely different more than fifty years ago when we raised the united Europe out of the water.
The diversity that characterizes us Europeans has become a defining factor in the lives of children.
The concept of diversity must therefore find its way into the pedagogy of the children's educators and teachers.
This is currently not being taken into account enough.
The childcare facilities and schools of Europe are breaking down in the face of the challenge of integration.
In questions of integration, we must press the reset button back to the start.
Let's approach this topic again completely free of prejudice, according to the motto Unity through Diversity and above all.

And in addition, I ask all the European Parliamentarians who follow me to not only fight for gender mainstreaming, but also for children's mainstreaming, especially now in the time of the global financial crisis, because otherwise we would incur immeasurable debts for our children. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President, I will keep it very short.
I thank you very much for the constructive contributions to the debate that I have heard here.
I would like to send out two messages at the end. First of all, I would like to thank the Commissioner for not speaking against the concept of minimum requirements for the security network.
This proposal is not a devil's stuff and it is not a bureaucratic monster.
It is an instrument for problem solving that we should give a chance.
Therefore, I would like to reiterate my support for this cause.
And the second thing I want to say, and this is now directed at my British friends, and that is cross all the parties, my.
My dear British friends, I understand Caroline, I understand your problem.
I can well understand that one sometimes prioritizes the energy security of a country over the compliance with a limit value for air pollution for a certain period of time.
I have great understanding for that.
I am also the last one who would not give your majesty additional time when it comes to building new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it.
The problem is we have not done exactly that.
This conversation has never taken place during the last four months.
I would like to ask you to be open minded at this point in the second reading and to say let's talk about a compromise at this point.
To give up the completely irrational, non-justifiable resistance to minimum standards from a competitive and environmental policy point of view.
I believe that this is the point where a compromise can be reached, which I hope will be achieved in the second reading.
By the way, I am not of the opinion that we should not be looking for a compromise in the first reading.
This legislation is too complex for that.
I do not want to end this legislature as a reporter and leave a legislation to the next parliament, because a text of a law is discussed that is not consistent, that is illogical and contradictory.
Therefore, I request support for the compromises if we vote in an hour. Thank you.
Yes, dear colleagues, I think the crucial question with all the economic stimulus programs that are now being coordinated across Europe is, of course, who will ultimately receive the money?
Will the banks still issue more blankoschecks, even though the rapid nationalization would ultimately be much cheaper for the taxpayer?
And should the corporations and high-income earners be further relieved, even though they have been stung by tax gifts throughout Europe for years?

The more money is wasted on such purposes, the more likely it is that such programs will fail and the more likely it is that the European economy will continue to sink downwards in a very dangerous downward spiral.

The long-standing policy of privatization, deregulation, and liberalization has concentrated incomes more and more among the top ten thousand, and it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
And who believes that he can overcome this crisis by continuing exactly this policy with minor modifications? I think he simply didn't understand anything.
The exact opposite of that is necessary.
Instead of buying bad papers from banks, funds should be used for the renovation of schools, hospitals, and the ecological restructuring of the European economy.

If private companies receive public funds, there must be no tax money without employment guarantees and, above all, no tax money without the acquisition of public property rights, so that the state and, above all, the general public can later participate in the future benefits.
The best economic program that exists at the moment would be a radical redistribution of income and wealth from the top to the bottom.
The low-wage sector in Europe must be pushed back, instead of being further promoted.
We need higher minimum wages, we need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that the millionaires and the profiteers of the past financial market party now also bear the immense losses that have arisen and not the large majority of citizens who have never benefited from the whole financial boom.
I think that the socially just is currently also the economically sensible.
And it is the only way to break through the devastating crisis dynamics.

Thank you, Mr. President. In early March, the political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedew were transferred from Chita in Siberia to Moscow to be charged again on the basis of untenable accusations.
The first public day of negotiations was scheduled for March thirty-first.
On the same day, the human rights consultations between the EU and Russia were supposed to take place.
These important talks have now been postponed indefinitely by the Russian side.
Russia thus clearly demonstrates the low value it places on human rights.
The judiciary is not only not used for justice, but is also used to eliminate regime opponents, and the EU is thus duped.

Mr President, thank you very much. Thank you very much, Commissioner. Thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen. I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for once again drawing attention to the ban on animal testing.

Hingewiesen hat, weil es mich daran erinnert, dass das jetzt die dritte Änderung der Kosmetikgesetzgebung ist, die ich begleiten durfte. Die sechste Änderung, die siebte Änderung und jetzt die Änderung zu einer Verordnung.
Und wir haben es in der Tat geschafft, Tierversuche zu verbieten.
We have managed to make consumers know how long a product is still consumable by seeing a small can with a number inside that says how long it is still valid.

I also say this to the address of some colleagues, especially the colleague Reutova, who unfortunately could not be there at the beginning. Labels are never warning signs. At no time would a product not be safe, then it may not be on the market, then it may not be marketed.
Every product on this European market must be safe and harmless.
But the labeling gives consumers the option to choose.
This is democracy and this is your freedom of choice.
Ich glaube, dass wir eine sehr gute Gesetzgebung haben.
Ich habe versucht, das Verfahren sehr transparent zu gestalten.
I have tried, as Ms. Krest said, to bring together different opinions.

Because it is my aim to make a legislation that is a good legislation for everyone, for the consumers in the European Union, for the industry that has to work with this legislation, and ultimately for all those who benefit from it.
With colleague Stellrecht, I say again, yes, the de o works differently for everyone, but the statement keeps you sweat-free, is still made.
Therefore, it is important that the statements regarding the depth of the fold around the eyes are somewhat real and reliable after a week in Strasbourg.
I would like to express my thanks to the Commissioner, also regarding the explanations he has given to my colleagues and to my employees, who have done most of the work.
Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the report by Commissioner Manzi on the Green Book and the future form of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most important of the Regio Committee in recent years.
Und wir stimmen dem grundlegenden Konzept des Grünen Buches zu, wonach es beim territorialen Zusammenhalt ja darum geht, die polyzentrische Entwicklung der EU.
Overall, as well as ensuring a sustainable development of the highland areas with various characteristics and peculiarities, and at the same time preserving their diversity.

And it is correct that in the next planning period, a more comprehensive system of gradual assistance for transition regions, which will exceed the threshold of seventy-five percent, will be implemented.
Prozent des Bruttoinlandsprodukts überschreiten werden, geschaffen werden muss, damit diese Regionen einen eindeutigen Status erhalten und somit mehr Sicherheit in ihrer Entwicklung haben.
And in the report by colleague Crees on obstacles to the initial uptake of structural funds, the most significant shortcomings are rightly listed, from which applicants suffer.
In Anspruchnahme der Strukturfonds stehen wie zum Beispiel übermäßiger Verwaltungsaufwand, zu viele komplexe Verordnungen, langsame und umständliche zentralisierte Verwaltung in den Mitgliedstaaten.
And manifold recommendations will be made to the Commission as to what effective measures should be taken to remove these obstacles.
I would like to take the opportunity to highlight and reinforce two such measures.
First of all, at present, project managers must keep their project documents for a period of ten years in order to have them available for checks that may be carried out by the Commission.
Especially for smaller projects, this is excessively bureaucratic effort.
Correct that this should now be reduced to a period of three years and secondly, the evaluation criteria of the EU Commission for innovative projects cause significant problems.
Innovative projects should not be subject to the same evaluation criteria as other projects, Mr. Colleague.
It is simply necessary that something else happens here.

Thank you, Madam President. If Europe takes money in hand and if, above all, the Member States take a lot of money in hand to help the automotive industry in its crisis-ridden situation, then it is not only a matter of securing the stock and the status quo and preventing bankruptcies, but it is also a matter of a number of other issues.
Die wichtigsten sind genannt worden.
It is about the people who are looking for employment. They need to secure this employment, and for a long time.
It is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation and above all sustainability in the transport system more than we have done so far.

We should therefore link all our measures with these objectives, so that we do not have to fall victim to the accusation in a few years. We should have thought of all this many years ago, otherwise we will not be in the next and new crisis.
Thank you, Madam President. It would be nice if you would also grant me half a minute, which my colleague from the Greens, Mrs Breyer, has just received.
The Commission had put forward a good proposal for the update of the Regulation on Novel Foods.

Unfortunately, some amendment proposals try to supplement this proposal with requirements that are not compatible with the objectives of the regulation or that even want to interfere with existing case law.
The obligation of food producers to monitor novel foods with regard to the health and well-being of animals would simply overwhelm the traders.

And again, there is the attempt to circumvent the existing GMO laws, namely the demand for a special labeling of such novel foods that are obtained from animals that are fed with genetically modified feed.
Wir haben es gerade gehört, ich denke.
In principle, everything that the GVO legislation concerns should not be addressed in the Novel Food Regulation.
I say this, although I myself had submitted the application, to specifically distinguish new plant species from the definition of novel foods.
Aber es kann nicht sein, dass Interessierte Kreise dieses Hauses die Novel Food Verordnung für Wahlkampfzwecke missbrauchen.
