This will make the right to informational self-determination of people, the right to be a person of color and the vision of a glassy person a reality.
Allow me, as an East German MEP, to conclude by stating that it is unbearable for me, twenty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, to witness Europe becoming more and more of a fortress.
Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, you are right. The railway system is a very safe system compared to other modes of transport.

However, in addition to many positive aspects, the liberalization in the form of fragmentation of individual companies, separation of infrastructure and operations, outsourcing of maintenance work and leasing of material and personnel has brought a lot of uncertainty.
It must be ensured, in my opinion, that the national security authorities issue the security certificates and approvals according to the provisions of the ERA, according to the railway agency.
Gibt es Kontrollen, genügend Kontrollen?
For example, it is ensured that the training of personnel, the certifications and the working conditions are properly controlled.
How does this relate to the introduction of a uniform community certificate?
What about the European truck driver license?
The efforts concerning ERTMS must be further increased.
The recently created implementation plan, as indicated by you, must be binding and must not be delayed by financial or national considerations.
The efforts concerning the introduction of the technical specifications TSI must be continued and expanded.
This would be a huge step forward, especially in the homologation of the material and in the maintenance of the material.
Many of the recent railway accidents and near accidents are due to inadequate maintenance.
For cost reasons, the intensity is particularly neglected and the intervals of maintenance work are extended.
What about a Europe-wide certification system for maintenance workshops?
In my opinion, everything must be done to prevent each individual member state from returning to its old rules and acting differently and independently again.
Especially the border crossings between the individual member states are a security risk.
How does the Commission plan to deal with this problem in a short time?
And in the balance sheet you are preparing, I would like you to take into account the social aspects, which are not forgotten. Thank you very much.
We need a revolution of democracy, Mr President, Mr Commissioner, good morning. In this new world of the Treaty of Lisbon, this is an opportunity for you.
For eleven years, I have been following your reports in this House, previously as a journalist, and ultimately they are very similar.
Now, however, you have the opportunity to look ahead.

Use the expertise of this House. It is not a coincidence that it is now gathered in the hall. I see colleagues Sondergaard, I see colleagues Tsakiris, there is Mr. Staes, there is Mr. Ehrenhauser from our list, my fellow debater, and set the work of the Court of Auditors anew.
Look at what works elsewhere in Germany, where you can check the economic efficiency and sensibility of the expenses in Austria and develop.
A concept, perhaps in the framework of an initiative report that will then come to Parliament, on how to do what you are doing much better, so that you can actually meet your tasks.
We need a revolution of democracy.
I remember very well that the debates we are hearing today began in this House ten years ago.
I would like to urge you, Commissioner, above all to write down what is coming from all of this, but also from Greens and some left-wing MEPs.

Don't you notice that with the approach with which the European Union went into the negotiations and is in them, we cannot eliminate the imbalance as a redoubtable broker? I think, in connection with what we are experiencing in these hours and days in Copenhagen, that we really need a new approach.
The developing countries are in many ways, what they are doing today, no longer developing countries.
Developed countries, developing countries and very self-confident.

If it is not possible from the European side to dare to start afresh with fair conditions, then we will end up where we do not want to go, namely with protectionism and, following nineteen thirty three, also in Europe.
Yes, thank you. I would like to use the blue card only for its intended purpose.
The support in Austria is not only provided for one person.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a microfinance instrument for the unemployed, threatened by unemployment, and especially for people who do not have access to normal credit markets, is a good intention, a good intention, and is supported in principle by our group.
However, what the Commission and the Council have achieved in this process so far is simply insufficient, sometimes incorrect, and cannot be supported by our group.
Erster Punkt der Kritik die Frage der Finanzausstattung.
What lies on the table in terms of financial resources is not financial support for a program to combat unemployment. This cannot be called a microfinance program. It is at most nanofinancing.
Secondly, we are fundamentally opposed to making such tricks without any effect, at the expense of other programs, and thus wasting them without end.
Thirdly, it is also the opinion that sustainability and success of such a program must include organic mentoring and coaching.
Many new startups, especially in the microfinance sector, fail. Therefore, it must also be ensured within the program.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in the Member States are not cancelled for the use of this program, otherwise it will be ineffective.
With this, unemployment cannot be sustainably combated.
Wir werden es in dieser Form ablehnen.
Thank you very much. After eight years, we all know that the previous Afghanistan strategy based on the military has failed.
The imbalance between military operations on the one hand and insufficient resources for civilian purposes on the other hand is preventing a real improvement in the living conditions in Afghanistan.
And that is why our most important message as UNGL is that a radical change of strategy is necessary.
We need a radical change of strategy away from the military and above all towards the people.
This means that forty percent of Afghans are unemployed, more than half of them live in truly bitter poverty, and neither have access to healthcare nor receive sufficient education.
The social question must be put at the forefront, and we expect this from the Council, from the Commission, from all those involved.
This includes, of course, strengthening responsible government action, strengthening agriculture, and integrating former Taliban fighters.
But I tell you quite honestly, whoever only goes halfway this way and then relies on military adventures again, is giving up every chance.
It is five minutes to twelve.
Frau Präsidentin, meine Frage geht in die Richtung, ist es nicht sinnvoll, Arbeitslosigkeit überhaupt zu verhindern?
Do you see public tasks that could be transferred to the unemployed?
And above all, how can we strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises, encourage new ones to be founded?
Are there possibilities here to apply methods and best practices across countries and create more and new undertakings?
We need a revolution of democracy.
As a lover of so many Swedish traditions, I was all the more disappointed in the balance of their activities.
It was unfortunately not a presidential term of the people's home, but rather a presidency of the councilors and also a presidency of the major investors of all the streams. It was not the streams.
I know you, Ms. MEP, from this time when you were still a member.
Now you are asking something else.
And I very much hope that when you come back, you will pick up where you left off, namely inspired by parliamentarism.
Warum haben Sie SWIFT so spät verabschiedet?
Why do we now have to deal with a quasi-directorate at EU level and that under the goals of Sweden with its transparency?
Please use your future to return to where you once were.
Thank you very much, Mr President, the current debate is a central debate about the character of the European Union.
The question is market or social policy?
Und die bisherigen Überlegungen der Kommission zur Zukunft der Kohäsionspolitik sind inakzeptabel.
Die Strukturfonds müssen gestärkt werden und nicht reduziert.
Europe must not do less, but more to overcome the economic and social development differences.

I say it quite openly, the renationalization, even just from parts of the current cohesion policy, would have serious consequences for disadvantaged regions, by the way, also in Germany, for example in East Germany.
And after the last round of expansion of the European Union, the differences between the regions in the Union have actually grown.
It is also important to me that particularly socio-economic conditions in the regions that are just above the seventy five percent threshold of the BIP per capita are also recognized.
An abrupt termination of funding after 2013 would be devastating for these regions.
Ladies and gentlemen, of course, the strengthening of specific urban funding, city-related funding by the European Union is extremely important.
Important, as there are great potentials for the economy and finances, and as the crisis has hit particularly hard there.
A final word on the border regions.
As an East German MEP, I tell you that we have to invest a lot, do a lot there.
And I have great concerns that the Commission will fail.

The regional structural funding is a key instrument in European integration, and especially the II funding has been perceived by people on the ground in many regions as a motor for structural and economic development.
And it is an important element for coping with structural change in the regions and also in the municipalities.
Here, Europe is also really tangible for the citizens, because it also has an effect on the ground.
However, we need simpler, clearer, and more transparent structures for cohesion funds and better controls to ensure that the funds are used sustainably and efficiently.
The cohesion, the convergence in social and economic development, is a main goal in the EU, and that is why we must not weaken this instrument in the future, but we must strengthen it.
The cohesion policy in Europe needs more clarity, more transparency, efficiency, and also the self-responsibility of the individual member states.
Und deshalb ist es wichtig, bei dem System der additiven Förderung zu bleiben.
Wir wollen aber keine Renationalisierung der Strukturförderung.
Therefore, I would like to ask the Commission to ensure that the funding criteria from 2013 meet these requirements.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have two motions to table. Mr President, I ask that you allow me to put them in order.
First of all, I have a request to the entire House.
The urgency that we are discussing this afternoon.
This is the case of Mrs. Amita Hay.
Wir haben heute Nachmittag eine Dringlichkeit auf der Tagesordnung.
I ask my colleagues to trust me to proceed with the following. Some colleagues who are dealing intensively with this case know and I can.
I cannot say more details now, but I am one of those who know that shortly before it is clear that we will have a solution for this case today during the course of the day.
Renowned government representatives of the EU are working on a positive solution.
It would therefore make sense for us to remove this urgency from the agenda this afternoon, because any further debate would only hinder the work that some diplomatic channels are doing there.
Therefore, my request is that the House agrees that we take this urgency out of the agenda on an exceptional basis, because we will help the solution of the case more than if we discuss it.
That would be my first request, Mr. President.
The second request I will make directly afterwards.

It seems to me to be a bit symptomatic for us, for the EU in general, but also for the Parliament in particular, that we reflexively have discussions about situations in countries whose situation is not new.
It is unfortunately the case that very often overnight events lead to us suddenly pouring into political demands here, which I sometimes find somewhat questionable.
I believe that it is not good for us to use a failed plane attack alone to provoke a general debate on Yemen.
I believe that we should be clear about the fact that it is good for us to consider a strategy for how we will deal with this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen requires a detailed analysis, namely that it is a failed state in which a government acts, which no longer has control over large parts of the country, and we should analyze for ourselves what risks for Europe arise from this.
The risks seem to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks seem to be increasing on the Yemeni coast, where piracy is obviously taking place.
That is why I think it is up to us and perhaps also to Ms. Ashton to consider what we can do about these risks.
In my opinion, the answer can be how can we help the government in Yemen to regain control of the country and to contain these risks?

All other discussions about the long-term development of the country must of course also be conducted. But I do not think that it is really sensible and that we will be taken seriously if we now propose a list of demands across all policy issues, from freedom of the press to the rights of women in parliament.
I believe that will not lead to the goal in Yemen, but we should focus on what help we can provide in the current situation to solve an acute problem. Thank you.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the massacre on 23 November last year in the province of Maguindanao in the Philippines was a black day for human rights and a barbaric act of terror.
Fifty-seven dead, raped women, injured. They speak a bloody language.
As a journalist, I am particularly struck by the fact that thirty journalists were among the dead.
According to the renowned International Crisis Group, no documented case has ever seen more journalists killed in one fell swoop.
For this reason, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to find clear words, as we are doing today in the resolution draft.

However, as the EVP, we demand to soften the present text in three places by separate vote, because we should support the Philippine government in its fight against terror and violence and therefore refrain from making too many accusations against the government.
Daher beantrage ich, im Namen der EVP, besonders über Erwägungsgrund F abzustimmen. Dieser klagt die Philippinen an, alle Anzeichen eines nicht funktionierenden legalen Systems aufzuweisen.
Quote in point two we want to eliminate the assumption of so-called initial delays in clarification.
Finally, in point six, it claims that there are missing persons who are in Philippine prisons.
This is also currently an unproven assumption and should be deleted in our opinion. Thank you.
Dear ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that the Social Democratic Group is working intensively on this report.

I would like to point out, however, that as a parliament we made a nearly unanimous decision in December 2008, in which we asked the European Commission to present exactly such a proposal as we are now discussing here.
And the Parliament must also be allowed to adhere to what it has decided and what has been the declared will of this House for years.
We have, because of course there are always concerns with every legislative proposal here or there, resolved the open questions through a compromise in the legal committee.
This compromise is, I must say, decisive.
I still have the understanding that it can of course make sense to expand the circle of those who support this report.
And if the efforts of colleague Schulz are directed towards expanding the circle of supporters, I have nothing against a postponement to the next plenary session in March.
Das ist meine persönliche Position.
It is not the attitude of the factions, which explicitly decided differently on this matter this morning.

But I think we should give the socialists the chance to come to their senses so that they can also do something for the middle class and for the relief of the middle class and the reduction of bureaucracy. Thank you.
Ich habe das verstanden.
The Almunia report was responsible.
I had asked you about your interventions, but can you now say again what you have done yourself?
Did I understand you correctly, Mr Barroso, that the fault for the Greek crisis lies with the Member States, because they refused to follow their proposals?
Und würden Sie uns bitte sagen, welche Regierungschefs welcher Mitgliedstaaten das waren?
"Herzlich Willkommen hier in diesem Hause."
Loss of trust in Copenhagen that was in my opinion one of the big problems.
Aber das könnte sich theoretisch fortsetzen, weltweit, aber auch innerhalb der Europäischen Union.
Meine Frage ist an Sie, wie geht das mit den Instrumenten, die wir im vergangenen Jahr beschlossen haben, weiter?
The ETS is already on my mind because I am not quite sure how the Commission is now dealing with benchmark, for example, and carbon leakage as a result of the decision in Copenhagen.
And the second question is there is a proposal from the French government to export importers from the
Dritten Welt wollen wir auch hier in das IT-System einzugliedern, um damit den Markt größer zu machen und diese Länder dann an diesem System teilhaben zu lassen.
What is your opinion on this matter?
Thank you very much, Madam President. It is a matter of driving a clear strategy as the European Union and preventing a gold or oil rush.
Europe must actively intervene here.
Here, Europe can prove its strength as a partner by speaking with one voice.
It is about shipping over and under water, it is about fishing, it is about resources in the form of primary energy sources and raw materials.
Here we need, together with the other partners in the ACTIS, sustainable and reliable agreements.
We need cooperation instead of confrontation.
We need the dialogue in the field of environmental protection to preserve natural resources and nature.
We need a dialogue in the field of animal welfare to preserve biodiversity. We need protection and respect for the residents and their human rights.
If we carry out positive resource management together with the partners in the ACTIS, we will have the chance to go politically new paths here.
It will also be a first nail test for our common foreign policy, where we can prove that we as Europeans pursue common goals. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the G20 summit in Pittsburgh has provided a good template.
He has called for economic recovery plans to promote decent work that contributes to the securing and creation of jobs and has given priority to employment growth.

The European Labour Ministers are therefore called upon to urge the G twenty members firstly not to reduce but to use the Conjuncture packages in a larger scope and more strongly for the creation of jobs. Secondly, financially secured short-time work.

To take action against the loss of jobs, thirdly, to use public investments to create jobs and sustainable ecological growth, and fourthly, to strengthen and expand social security measures to enable access.
This also secures purchasing power in the domestic market and employment and combats poverty.

The cooperation with the social partners is particularly important to the Ministers of Labour of Europe in order to strengthen the social dialogue even more, as the Commissioner would like to strengthen.
Yes, Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, thank you very much to Mr. Leichtfried for an excellent report that carries good and good content.
What is it about?
It is about strengthening transparency, consumer protection, security, coordination, and quality management.
I warn you, however, not to set up a new authority to deal with these issues.
I see the subsidiarity in the report as positive. It should definitely be retained.
For me it is also very important to have a clear separation between taxes and fees and all tasks that are sovereign, be they recognition services.
Police, whether it is counter-terrorism or the like, all these measures are clearly to be financed from tax money and not from user fees.
If individual nation states have a vital interest in taking security measures beyond this, then I also see them as being cost-bearing in this area.
Wer die Sicherheit im hoheitlichen Bereich in Auftrag gibt, bezahlt sie auch.
I see it differently, certainly in the technical or personal area, which can certainly be at the expense of the air passenger, if it is clearly declared what it is about.
It is noteworthy, however, that in the area of the impact assessment that the Commission has presented to us, a figure of about 0.1 percent of the total funding is calculated for these measures.
We should not start too high.
I believe that we can also reach a sustainable compromise with the Federal Republic of Germany, which has extraordinary concerns in the area of subsidiarity.
I wish that the final result is very close to our proposal. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Commissioner, Mr. Council President, with the evaluation of the passenger data, similar to Swift, attempts are being made to combat global terrorism.
To reconcile the serious crime with the fundamental rights of every individual to protect privacy and also to information self-determination.
However, we must also be aware that in Europe and worldwide in the age of mobility, there will be no sufficient security without an effective and rapid data exchange.
And in the digital age, we must also ensure special protection for the informational self-determination and privacy.
I therefore also consider it necessary to distinguish more precisely between the data necessary for combating crime and the data sensitive to privacy.
And for me it is actually not a question at all that we have to integrate controls, legal remedies, information rights, claims for damages, and the length of the storage period into the agreement.
In the case of the push method, it must be checked whether exceptions can or must be made in urgent cases.
And with regard to the use of passenger flight data, we should also include serious criminality.
And for me, these include the crimes such as child pornography, human trafficking, murder, rape, and drug trafficking.
And that, in my opinion, would also be a contribution to the protection of the personality rights of those affected.
Ich finde es gut, dass wir die Entscheidung über die in Frage stehenden Fluggastdatenabkommen vertagen, um ein Grundmodell für alle künftigen Abkommen dieser Art.
Auch zu entwickeln und um der Kommission auch einen Verhandlungsrahmen mit auf den Weg zu geben, das unsere eigenen Vorstellungen im Datenschutz eben mit berücksichtigt.
Perhaps in the future there will also be room to think about conducting the fight against terrorism and crime with our transatlantic partners in a joint institution.
Und das wäre mit Sicherheit auch ein Schritt der globalisierten Kriminalität, auch global entgegenzutreten. Danke.
Yes, thank you. We have rightly pointed out the importance of the EIB in the previous speeches.
Colleague Kadenbach, for example, spoke of the necessary contribution to social convergence.
Ich möchte das in einen politischen Kontext stellen.
We are deeply concerned that in more and more states, parties of the extreme right are gaining ground.
They do that because the social convergence in the European Union does not work as we all wanted it to.
They very often portray these extreme right-wingers as a wolf in sheep's clothing, thus hiding a massive cynical contempt for human beings behind it.
Last example, Mr. President, I also know your political attitude, what Mr. Mölzer just did, he gives a very nice speech, but in between he calls a political opponent me a psychopath.
Das ist die Sprache des Hitlerfaschismus, das ist die Art, wie die arbeiten. Da wurden auch schon politische Gegner zu Unmenschen gestempelt.

I ask you to take action against it, and I ask the colleagues from the EIB to continue their work, also in the area of transparency, to become a little more transparent, because their procedure is also a help for the upcoming new fascism.
Political coherence in the interest of development means that we do not take with one hand what we give with the other.

It makes little sense, for example, to invest subsidies in the development of agriculture in developing countries if we destroy the local markets at the same time through direct or indirect export subsidies.
We can also not be so committed to better health care if we hinder trade with generics or drive drug prices to unreasonably high levels through patent extensions.

And agrofuels may reduce CO2 emissions in the EU a little, but they lead to deforestation and land conversion in developing countries and thus to more climate change, which we just wanted to avoid. Not to mention the displacement of indigenous peoples, loss of biodiversity and agricultural land for food.
At the moment, we are, that is, the EU as such, not particularly coherent.
The EU has long recognized in theory that political measures should not contradict each other.
The Lisbon Treaty stipulates political coherence in the interest of development.
In article two hundred eight it says, in the implementation of political measures that can affect developing countries, the Union takes into account the goals of development cooperation.
We must measure ourselves against this demand.
This year, we are reviewing the progress made in achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
It is clear without political coherence we will not succeed in fulfilling our promise.

We must become aware of this responsibility, we all who make and implement laws. Before we decide on a measure, there must be an assessment of the consequences, so that we can at all recognize what negative effects the European legislation can have on developing countries.
We need expertise in the Council, Commission and Parliament that recognizes incoherences.
The Commission's work programme on political coherence is a good step in this direction.
Und jetzt kommt es darauf an, wie dieser Plan umgesetzt wird.

Political coherence in the interest of development means that we must take the interests of the people on the ground into account more when reforming fisheries, and not subordinate the interests of European fishing companies.
It means that we have to dry up tax havens into which funds from developing countries flow.
It means that we ACTA cannot agree if there is a suspicion that this agreement could interfere with access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
So far, the Commission has not been able to dispel this suspicion.

Political coherence also means that in the creation of the External Service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy field and the competences of the Development Commissioner must be expanded and not restricted.
And it is also part of it that we, for example, enable fair trade in the awarding of contracts in municipalities, as my colleague Heike Ruhle has proposed.
In many cases, we Members of Parliament, the Commission and the Council must keep a close eye on the finger so that they shape policy coherently.
In many cases, however, it is also our responsibility as Members of Parliament to be consistent in the interest of development.
We need to better network between committees and we need a permanent rapporteur.
The report that the development committee unanimously adopted makes many good suggestions and brings us a big step forward.
I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the ombudsman, and all the NGOs for their assistance and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can be accepted by the plenary tomorrow.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have taken from the roll call list that you, Mr President, intend to declare the second motion inadmissible.
I ask you to reconsider this again.
Is it indeed correct that Article 229 of the Treaty provides for a meeting of the European Parliament to take place on the second Tuesday of March?
Das steht aber nicht im Widerspruch zu dem Antrag, der hier von meiner Fraktion gestellt worden ist.
The motion of my group aims to postpone the Strasbourg week from the tenth week to the eleventh week.
This does not prevent you from holding a plenary session on Tuesday, March second.
We want the Strasbourg Week to be in the eleventh week, so that I can say there is no iniquity here.
I would ask you to reconsider this again. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. Commission President, in response to my colleague Manfred Weber's questions, has Commissioner Malmström informed the College that there are serious concerns about the current state of negotiations in this House?
Is the Commission aware that what it has decided today is certainly not what the Parliament considers to be sufficient progress?

Are you aware, Mr. President, that you have accepted something today, that if it is implemented, it will result in employees of a private company, such as the Swift company, having more control rights than officials of the European Union?
Did Ms. Malmström clarify these things to you?
If so, how could they have decided?
If not, why didn't Mrs. Malmström clarify this?
Thank you very much, Mr President, for the kind descriptions of your debate.
That was not the answer to my question.
Therefore, I will try to be more precise and I ask you to answer very precisely.

Did Ms. Malmström tell you during the debate in the Commission before the decision of the College that with the text you are now presenting as an agreement, there is a danger that Parliament will vote no?
Or did Mrs. Malmström tell you that we will get a parliamentary majority with this text?
I repeat very precisely, did Ms. Malmström say with this text we will get a parliamentary majority, or did she say with this text the parliamentary majority is not safe?
Ich wäre Ihnen dankbar, wenn Sie präzise.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for months we have been discussing the question of these lead times and working hours in road traffic.
And I wonder what arguments are being used to prove that what we have been discussing for months is all nonsense.
The latest argument is that something must be changed here urgently, so that nothing changes.
Do not notice, dear Mrs. Bauer, how absurd this argumentation is now, how it is enforced by lies and half-truths.
This dispute is all about extending the working hours of self-employed people.
In the realm of labor law, however, the issue of protecting people from excessive working hours has been a matter of principle for one hundred and fifty years.
This applies to both the self-employed and the employees.
It doesn't matter if you are self-employed, who is overwhelmed, or if an employer, an employee, a driver is overwhelmed.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessive working hours, sometimes also from employers and clients.
Secondly, in terms of road safety, it is claimed here that nothing can happen.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not in the hobbyist market and we are not mere craftsmen. We cannot make laws. Let's see what comes out of it.
Everyone knows that excessive working hours are associated with being at risk of accidents, especially in road traffic with significant consequences.
Third point, who is supposed to control the roads with such differentiated regulation that you imagine in the future?
Today, a state labor court judge cannot check whether someone is self-employed or self-employed without extensive file study.
Let this nonsense go. It's about fair competition.
It is not about setting a precedent for the future dispute over the extension of working hours.
Don't play such tricks with this house. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. As I have been for many years, I advocate for road safety, an improvement in the working conditions of our professional drivers, and the upgrading of their profession.

Clearly, today is not about the traffic safety relevant regulations for driving and rest periods that all self-employed and employed professional drivers must comply with. Today, it is about the regulation of working hours.
It is primarily a regulation for the protection of employees, so it serves only the social protection of drivers and not at all for traffic safety.
We must not protect self-employed people from themselves.
The compliance with working hours is neither controllable nor is there a comprehensible reason why it should be controlled at all for self-employed truck and bus drivers.
To limit self-employed professional drivers, as well as perhaps self-employed craftsmen, architects, or members of parliament in their permissible working hours in the future, is the wrong signal.
Rather, the Member States should ensure that the apparent independence of the
The drivers.
Thank you, Madam President. Congratulations to the rapporteur, but also to our shadow rapporteur. I believe that a good report has been produced here.
The essential message for me is that both sides, which are currently making life difficult in Bosnia and Herzegovina, must finally have insight and retreat from their extreme positions.

One extreme position is to repeatedly question the integrity of the country and threaten referendums that can do nothing but create tension and hatred. The other extreme position is to question the basic structure of the state.
Muss doch eben adaptiert werden.
Ja.
It has already been adopted and more needs to be done.
And if it is always said on one side that the office of the High Representative should be dissolved, I agree with that.
But the side that demands this must create the conditions for it to be possible for the politicians in the country to take responsibility themselves.
This must be our goal, but politicians must also take responsibility.
And hopefully the voters in the next elections will also elect those politicians who are willing to take responsibility for their own country. Thank you.

President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, just a few days ago we saw with shock in the television images how wide areas of Poland and other Central European countries were flooded by water.
People have died in the floods and the relatives deserve our full sympathy. Villages, cities and agricultural land, as well as infrastructure, have been destroyed.
The images on television have already been replaced by other images. However, the massive damage must first be painstakingly removed.
In the elimination of the damage of this magnitude, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the countries of the European Union.
After the flood disaster of nineteen ninety seven, Poland and this time also other Central European states, so again affected by a flood disaster.
We cannot regulate the weather yet, and floods are a natural occurrence for rivers at certain times.
Aber die Fragen, die wir stellen müssen, sind, ob im Bewusstsein dessen, dass es diese Naturereignisse immer geben kann, die richtigen Maßnahmen zur Vorbeugung gegen.
Damage caused by such natural events and whether, for example, the questions of sustainable disaster protection were adequately taken into account in landscape planning.
If aid is granted, it should first and foremost benefit those directly affected by the natural disaster.

However, in international cooperation, the natural disaster should not be stopped at national borders. More should be done by the Member States, coordinated at the European level, to prevent damage from natural disasters.
The fact that jointly operated precautionary measures can provide protection is shown by the flood protection on the Oder, which has so far been jointly built there by Polish and German authorities.
Aber wir sind da längst noch nicht am Ende.
We do not need a European disaster relief.
The protection of one's country from disasters should be the primary task of the government of a country, for which the creation of disaster plans should also be part.

But a coordination of aid in the event of damage should also be an efficient European coordination. And those organizations that provide help quickly and without bureaucracy on a voluntary basis should not be left to their own devices.
Therefore, I support the plans of Commissioner Georgieva that we implement them quickly.
Unfortunately, my sources of illness have so far prevented me from speaking in the international public in the same clarity as I have already done on other European issues.
But in a minute, Mr President,
You are in a historical time.
They will be measured in the area of financial markets, the most pressing issue, whether they succeed in introducing regulations that actually close loopholes.
Currently, everything that comes from the Commission and what we have in Parliament so far does not rule it out.

There are no necessary improvements. They will then stand in history as one who, as the House has already been burned down in the dark, has not provided the necessary extinguishing material and certainly not for new construction materials.
Point two equity. If it is not possible to stop this so threatening, devastating shadow banking system and not just to contain it, they will then withdraw.
Real economy and also billions of citizens around the world not only their own basis for action in the economic, but also the trust in everything that is called democracy.
Because then China and the totalitarians, who are already looking forward to their banks being controlled, are suddenly better off than the European Union.
And point three, of course, we need a system that minimizes systemic risks, so too big to fail can be implemented with progressive tax regulations that if a bank gets too big, it has to be closed.

Thank you. 2007 and 2008 Libya voted against the resolution of the United Nations General Assembly, which calls for a moratorium on executions, and also the repeated request of human rights organizations. There were no official statements.
Therefore, it is very important to us that it is finally officially presented which persons were executed.
Every execution is one too many.
We reject executions and death penalties.
It is inhuman, inhumane, and each is one too many.
Therefore, we very clearly request in our resolution that we change this and that we disclose and that we now work together to ensure that a change takes place here.

No more dark figures, but open information about what is happening here and a humane punishment for real offenders, but not an exaggerated punishment for those who deal critically with the regime in Tripoli.
Thank you, Mr. President. I wanted to support the motion of my colleague Conbent in the name of our group.
Wir sehen es genauso.
This is a highly sensitive, very delicate issue, and it is certainly sensible to find a broad parliamentary majority.
Therefore, it would be good if the report could be postponed and the attempt could be made to work out possible agreements.
Deshalb unterstützen wir diesen.
Dear colleagues, in the short time I have, I would like to confine myself to the Kantschian report.
It is undisputed that passenger rights and thus also consumer rights in road transport must be implemented.
However, I would like to emphasize again what problems small and medium-sized companies are currently facing, especially from the perspective of the Federal Republic of Germany.
Public local and regional transport cannot be separated, especially in rural areas, as they often serve a radius of about fifty kilometers together.
Secondly, it is not possible to provide debt independent advance payment of services for small and medium-sized enterprises.
Here we have the principle of liability, which has proven to be very good so far and has thus also kept the fares stable.

Thirdly, I cannot imagine that not culpable delays on the part of the entrepreneur have to be paid, just as liability can only be imposed for the circumstances that are attributable to the entrepreneur.
Thank you, Mr. Zeller, one and a half minutes. Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, a heartfelt thanks to Mathieu Grosch for this profound report and the enormous work he has done.

That Europe without dividing borders is not feasible without a functioning transportation system, and the European economy would not be successful without a capable transportation system, without efficient, future-proof transportation systems on land, water, and in the air. Not even conceivable.
In particular, we need even more community and less nationalistic selfishness in environmentally friendly rail transport.
For a sustainable future of transport, all modes of transport must meet the challenges in society, in the protection of the environment and in the economy.
The report provides valuable and guiding information on this.
Only in one point I cannot agree with the report, however, I cannot agree to the establishment of a traffic fund from the means of cohesion policy.
Why?
Certainly, transport is a special contributor to cohesion in Europe. However, a separate fund from the resources of cohesion policy would not meet the expectations it arouses.
The cohesion fund unilaterally burden and the Member States, which are particularly called upon to ensure a sustainable future of transport, are all too often relieved.
And we have just set up a special committee in Parliament to discuss how the cohesion and structural funds of the European Union will look in the future. Its work should not be prioritized.
Therefore, I also request that the amendment to the report be approved.
And I also think that when we talk about the sustainability and future of transport systems, the maglev technology should also be given a future and a chance. Thank you.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have a common internal market, but a fragmented supervision.
Dass das nicht funktionieren kann, liegt auf der Hand.
We need strong, central European structures that use the expertise and detailed knowledge of the member states' organs, but also have the authority to intervene in an emergency.

I believe that the citizen expects, on the basis of the enormous tax burden that has been imposed by this crisis, that a decision will be made quickly, swiftly, and in a manner that is appropriate to the facts.
The citizens are not interested in national level power games where the only question is who decides.
What the citizen wants is for decisions to be made effectively, for problems to be solved.

And that is objectively so that, when it comes to emergency measures, this must be centrally regulated and decided at European level if coordination between the Member States is not sufficient and does not work.
That is not in line with the decisions of the G20, the G8, the heads of state and government, unfortunately not at the level of the Council.
The Council is making a small, small, small contribution.
This is not an acceptable policy for the citizens.
We expect the Council to act. Thank you.

My Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, one sometimes wonders what we have actually been doing for over a year now, in discussions and debates, in many meetings in the trilogue, where I could have imagined something nicer than spending them there.

And at the present time, more than a year after the European elections, where we had announced on the streets and squares how we wanted to tame the financial markets, we are actually facing a very meager to non-existent result.
Und das Problem wurde schon beschrieben.
Wir haben es mit Märkten zu tun, die heute global agieren.
And the Member States still believe that they are able to enforce the rules of the game with their national supervisory structures.
And it is precisely because this did not work that it did not trigger the financial crisis, but it did contribute to the fact that Europe was hit.

And that is why I am already asking myself the question when this realization, which is often formulated in the Sunday speeches, is also implemented in political action, where it suddenly becomes a matter of protecting stock exchanges, where it is a matter of protecting bank structures and no longer protecting citizens.

We, the European Parliament, have dedicated ourselves to this task, and I hope that the Member States will also devote themselves to it, because they are jointly responsible for ensuring that the citizens implement proper supervisory rules that ensure that the savings of the individual are permanently secure.
I, of course, hope that the Commission will do everything in its power to reach a good result as quickly as possible in the interest of the people of Europe.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are in this European Parliament responsible for strong regulation of the financial markets.
All that we have proposed has been greatly improved in the trilogues.
Rat und Regierung wollen keine starken Eingriffsrechte.
Giegold is right when he has described it as church tower thinking, which is what is currently happening.
Not strict regulation, but only to construct the system a little more trouble-free seems to be the intention.
We will get a fragmented supervisory structure that will not be able to provide real control of the financial markets.
Insufficient consequences are being drawn from this financial crisis, and thus the next crisis is already being prepared.
Many national economies, including those in Europe, will not withstand the next blows with all the social and economic consequences for the people in Europe.
What you expect is that this predator financial market capitalism will be caught again and the primacy of politics will be restored.

Wenn der Vorstandsvorsitzende der Unicredit Bank, Alessandro Profumo, am Wochenende formuliert, wir brauchen eine starke und einheitliche europäische Finanzaufsicht und eine gemeinsame Regelung für alle.
Die Mitgliedstaaten und er plädiert für strengere Kapitalregeln. Dann ist das ein Appell an dieses Parlament, diese Regeln auch wirklich zu konstituieren.
It is the responsibility of this European Parliament to put pressure on the Council to urgently implement effective regulation. It would only be the first step towards a status quo ante.
Let them finally follow through on their wholehearted promises. My group advocates for strong European regulation.
Anything else, no regulation would be a danger to the euro, to a common EU and to democracy. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr President, for this statement.
I would like to see the Dutch team win and it would be the last time at this World Cup.
Probably a bad omen because we are no longer allowed to watch and then they probably won't win.

But on the subject, Mr. Commissioner, yes, you are giving the right signal. Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President, we are closing a package of laws today or tomorrow, which we have been discussing for more than two years.

It is not only the controversy that is to blame, but also an intervening European election and the coming into force of a new EU treaty, which has led to the fact that we had to make some adjustments.

But I think if we draw a conclusion from this debate today, I come to the conclusion that we now vote on a compromise, in which it is quite worthwhile to say yes, even if you do that in one or the other place, perhaps with a clenched fist in your pocket.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
One is the environmental requirements for industrial plants.
It is about us better promoting the best available technology in Europe.
I believe that we have found an exception paragraph in the current compromise, which gives the EU Commission, Mr. Potocnik, the right tool in its hands.

In the next few years, we will have to pay more attention than before to the fact that the approximately fifty two oh, oh, industrial plants in Europe should use the best available technology better than they do today.
I have heard many arguments in this debate.
One I would like to pick up on and also reflect here, because I can't understand it at all.
It was often said to me that the use of the best available technology is too expensive and we are thus endangering the competitiveness of the European industry even more in the crisis.
I am reluctant to recall my past, but I come from the former GDR, East Germany.
The economic and ecological collapse of the GDR was also due to the fact that investment in the latest technology was neglected for decades.

And I believe that every industry, every industrial enterprise, is called upon to invest in the latest technology because otherwise it loses its competitiveness and, of course, also reduces pollutant emissions.
I think we have the chance today to pass a law that improves this starting situation.
The second part of the directive, and this is a bit of the ballad fist I mentioned, are the large combustion plants.

We are talking about once again, we have already done it in the last directive, about renewed exceptions until the year twenty twenty, partly twenty twenty three for large combustion plants that do not have to meet the environmental requirements, in particular the air pollution limits.
I am addressing the Council here, perhaps also a little to all of us, that we must think very carefully about how sensible it is for us to regularly.
Ambitious environmental goals welcome, also discuss and welcome here, but whenever it comes to implementing them, to put them into concrete legislation, then a tragedy begins in Europe.
Then the member states will suddenly realize what it costs, what bills they have to pay, and then usually those who have gone into advance payments are also punished.
There are a number of Member States that are already complying with the requirements and are left behind in the end.
And I say it again here, both in the case of industrial plants and in the case of large combustion plants, we are not talking about science fiction in the essential coal-fired power plants.
We are not talking about things that are not available, but it is the latest state of technology.
Best available techniques, what is available on the market under competitive and cost aspects, can be installed in these plants. And against this background, we conclude.
Today we are presenting a package of laws, which I believe is better than what is currently in force, and therefore I encourage us all to agree to it.

And I also thank the colleagues who have worked with very hard bandages for the last two years, for their support, for their cooperation and above all that almost all important factions have signed this compromise. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Three of his things happened while we were debating. First of all, it is clear that Europe will become the football world champion.
A good omen, I think.
Who will be the winner?
I don't want to give any preferences.
Two Germany gets compliments from UK.
Chris Davis: Thank you very much. It doesn't happen every day.
It is worthwhile to keep this in mind.
And thirdly, the world is still in order. Even among the Greens, football is more important than environmental protection.
Unfortunately, our colleague Bas Aikhoud is also gone again.
But congratulations to our Dutch friends.
Two aspects I wanted to say to the debate that was just allowed to follow.
First, I understand all the worries and concerns of my Eastern European friends all too well.
I am also a half Eastern European as an East German.
And I understand that not every environmental policy step that has been taken in Western European countries in recent decades can be immediately followed in Eastern Europe.
Environmental protection at a high level must be affordable.
Yes, that's correct.
But I believe that even if you take this sentence into account, it is worth voting for this compromise, because it will be fair to the different starting situations that many Member States are in.
And secondly, the argument that the use of best available techniques endangers competitiveness, especially against China. This argument is not only wrong, it is even dangerous.
We have to deal with the fact that industrial processes in Asia are definitely cheaper than here.
And we will only be able to compete in this competition if we use the best available technology in all industrial branches.
Whoever does not do this loses competitiveness.
No one is asking for this law to shut down an industrial plant tomorrow.
No one is asking for the jump from zero to one hundred to achieve any threshold value within a week.
We have enough transition periods, but to say that one should refrain from it for competitive reasons is wrong.

And I believe that with the directive here, we have not only made an environmental policy, but I believe also an industrial policy concession, which is worth working on in the next few years. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the colleagues of the other groups for the preparation of my report on Kosovo, and also Mrs Ewa Mar, who has done very valuable work in the secretariat.

Ich hoffe, dass diese Entscheidung diese Meinung dann eine Gelegenheit sein wird, so was wie ein ein Open Window, wie es auf Englisch heißt, um die regionale Zusammenarbeit auf eine neue Basis zu stellen, aber von der Eigenstaatlichkeit.

Is Kosovo going to be independent and from independence and to make it clear that the common future for all states in the region, for Serbia, for Kosovo and all others as a member of the European Union is on the way there. Also the problems that still exist must be solved.

Because the citizens of the country, especially the young ones, should not have the impression that they live in an isolated state. They cannot go out while everyone else in the area will soon have this future.
I think that is the task.
I hope that I will find a large majority for this tomorrow in the plenary.

I have also tabled a new amendment that expresses a strong regret about the outbreaks of violence in recent days and hopes for rapid and independent clarification, and does not take this as a basis for an escalation of emotions in the coming days and weeks. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President, dear High Representative, dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the latest events in Kyrgyzstan, the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people.
The low burn of houses and the streams of thousands of refugees who left their hometowns and tried to flee from violence. All of this shook me and caused me to feel sympathy for the victims.
At the same time, this event in Kyrgyzstan also once again sheds light on the situation in Central Asia, which we here in the European Parliament cannot leave untouched.
On the contrary, we should devote our full attention to the countries of this region.

In doing so, we should not only focus on the states that are rich in natural resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but all states equally within the framework of the 2007 Central Asia strategy.
I think that is our obligation.
Die Staaten Zentralasiens, die sich vor noch nicht einmal 20 Jahren aus der einst mal zaristischen und späteren sowjetischen Herrschaft befreiten, tragen ein schweres Erbe.
Stalin's arbitrary drawn borders, without regard for the home regions of the peoples living there, apparently make it more difficult to live together within and outside the borders of these states.
Armut, Korruption, Missachtung von Menschen und Minderheitenrechten, autoritäre Regime, wirtschaftliche Verhältnisse wie zum Beispiel in Tadschikistan und Kirgisistan Hunderttausende.
Die Arbeitsimmigration zwingen und wie jetzt in Kirgisistan gestehen Konfliktlösungen mit Gewaltanwendung lassen den Weg dieser Staaten in die Zukunft mit Fragezeichen versehen.
Here we must not only watch, but the European Union must act.

If we do not want to let the path of these states lead to fundamentalist structures, if we do not want to deliver people there to dictatorial regimes in the long term, we need to use our full capacity.
In addition to the urgently needed material aid, we need the contact with these states, the active support for the developing democratic forces there.
Give the Prime Minister Rosa Otunbayeva a chance in the pacification of Kyrgyzstan and on the path to stable political relations. Let us give the debate here and tomorrow a chance.

The resolution should also be followed by actions so that the people in Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian states feel that we are not leaving them alone or handing them over to undemocratic forces on their path to the future.
The expectations of us Europeans in these countries are high. We should not disappoint them. Thank you very much.
"Bericht gestimmt aus 4 Gründen."
The architecture of the service has numerous weaknesses, the subtleties of which will cause us great concern.
The second point is that the European Ambassador will manage Commission funds in the future.
This exposes the funds to a multitude of risks, and the safeguards for these risks are still absolutely unclear.
The third point is the task of rights of this Parliament in a Council regulation.
Wir sind in diesem Verfahren in der de facto Mitentscheidung, doch haben wir es zugelassen, dass die Ratsverordnung Parlamentsrechte vorwegnimmt.
Deswegen möchte ich vor meinem Dossier die Haushaltsordnung sagen, dass ich mich durch die heutigen Beschlüsse nicht gebunden sehe.
The fourth point is the question of how we actually deal with each other in Parliament.

Wir haben in der letzten Periode eine Parlamentsreform beschlossen und Verfahren, die wir jetzt alle mit Füßen getreten haben, auch mit Zustimmung des Präsidiums und auch mit Zustimmung des Präsidenten.
Why do we make a parliamentary reform that prescribes procedures if we, when it comes to it, already violate them and do not comply with them?
Aus diesen Gründen kann ich diesem Bericht nicht zustimmen. Herzlichen Dank.
Thank you very much, Mr President, Mr Commissioner, I am very much in favour of green genetic engineering, but cloning is something else.
This cannot be compared with anything else.
Cloning is animal cruelty and many colleagues have already said it here.
I also presented it before the summer break in the discussion we had, only a fraction of the animal clones is actually viable.
And those who survive, many of them die very, very early, and in a very painful way.
Sie leiden unter Missbildungen von Extremitäten, von Organen.
Sie haben Immunschwächen, sie sind krankheitsanfällig.
This means pain and suffering and this painful dying.
How can we answer that?
We are so committed to animal welfare, and then we want to support such a technology.
No, we don't want that, and that's why we decided in July that we don't want any clone meat and no animal products from cloned animals.
And that is also only consequent.

Yes, we know that the products from cloned animals or their offspring are probably not harmful to health, and I personally assume that they would actually be suitable for human nutrition. But there is actually no shortage of meat from conventional production.
Why should we allow ourselves to be influenced by this clone?
Es ist doch völlig unnötig, diese Tierquälerei zu betreiben und die Bevölkerung will es eben auch nicht haben.
The population does not want these products. We do not need them. There is no argument for clone meat in the European Union.
And that is why we want a very clear regulation explicitly for cloned animals and yes, also for their offspring.
Ich will ein Verbot des Klonens und von Klonprodukten in der Europäischen Union und ich glaube auch, dass wir das durchsetzen können.
Of course, this also has to be related to imports.
Und ich will sicher sein, dass mir nicht klammheimlich Klonfleisch untergeschoben wird, weil es nicht gekennzeichnet ist, wie es eben hier schon geschehen ist.
Schottland. Und ich glaube nicht, dass man alles Fleisch zurückverfolgen kann.
Bei Rindfleisch mag es möglich sein.
But with pork, due to the mass produced, it will not be possible to trace back whether it was actually a clone in the line of ancestry.
In principle, I think yes, it is a fundamental question, it is an ethical question.
And other colleagues have said that we must also deal with ethical issues, and we are responsible for ethical issues.
And of course, there is the question of animal welfare, but there is also another question.

The experience shows I am a producer, I have studied this. The experience shows that all reproduction techniques, as soon as they really worked in animal production, were ultimately applied to humans.
And so we must ask ourselves today, do we want and can we use cloning technology in the not too distant future, and can we also accept it in humans?
So ich will das nicht und ich kann das auch nicht.
And even if a spare part clone in the future could perhaps donate a vital organ, a clone of myself, then I would not want that.
Und ich glaube nicht, dass das eine übertriebene Horrorvision ist.
Ich glaube, dass das in der Zukunft gar nicht allzu viel möglich wäre, wenn wir das Klonen erlauben würden.
And that is why we urgently need a ban, not only on cloning, but also on cloned animals and their offspring throughout the EU.
Und ich habe keine Angst vor der WTO.
Wir können das durchsetzen.
We don't have to copy everything the US is doing with all transatlantic friendship. Thank you.
Thank you very much, colleagues. It is no coincidence that we cannot agree so easily in this case, because two incompatible issues are mixed here.
We probably would have been able to agree well on trademark protection if we had focused on it.
Aber die Vermischung mit der Materie Internet ist auch sachlich falsch, weil es hier neue, andere Strategien braucht als im materiellen Recht.
This cannot be simply transferred.
Furthermore, it must be clear that we pay for every criminal prosecution on the net with interventions in civil rights, because you cannot see or find out about it yourself.
Und das das Dritte ist für mich wirklich klar wenn ich Kulturgenuss im Web schon unter Strafdrohung stelle, so dass ich mich praktisch schon immer mit einem Fuß.
Gefängnis befinde, wenn ich ins Netz hineinschaue, dann werde ich die Chancen, die das Internet auch für Kunst und Kultur und Kreativität bietet, nicht nutzen können.
Therefore, my appeal is to continue talking about it.
Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,
Mr. Chairman, property, whether it is intellectual or physical property, is a cornerstone of the market economy.
And that is why I believe it is important that we think about how we can regulate this issue in a good consensus with each other.
Wir brauchen auf alle Fälle ein.
Stop shop. It must become easier for consumers, for the self-employed, for small and medium-sized enterprises to get the appropriate licenses here.
And the availability of licenses for rights of intellectual property that are valid throughout the EU is of particular importance.
We need a market for intellectual property.
We need, above all, the original language, so that it is available throughout Europe.
Every language is an important cultural asset, and it should be possible to grant licenses for a language that are valid throughout Europe and can therefore be used by all citizens.
We need interoperability and technical neutrality to be able to use this intellectual property accordingly.
And we also need sanctions for those who violate competition and trade law.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have taken note that the Council does not wish to discuss the annual financial framework.

I would like to inform the Council that the European Parliament would like to discuss it and that the Council cannot behave like in kindergarten and say it will not answer us to our questions and also not to our suggestions.
Secondly, I must ask the Council in this context whether it wants Lisbon or whether it does not want Lisbon.
Lissabon is not a purely technical change, but means more tasks, means more task fulfillment, and thus also to answer related financial issues.
Furthermore, the Council has made decisions that lead to new financial expenditures.
This has been explained by many colleagues.

Wenn der Rat dies möchte und wenn der Rat möchte, dass nicht mehr Geld ausgegeben werden sollte, dann muss der Rat aber auch sagen, wo konkret möchte er einsparen, wie möchte er einsparen, wo möchte er exakt umschichten und nicht nur allgemeine.

Proportional shifts and then leave it to the Parliament and the Commission to decide where they have the discontent to decide, especially since the possibilities for reshuffling and changing the budget for us are extremely limited.

The tasks that they assign us additionally are so challenging that they do not contain small, insignificant sums, but I will only mention the areas of financial solidity of our states and their corresponding financial difficulties.
Wenn das Programm in Anspruch genommen werden muss, dann sind das keine Kleinsummen, die man so nebenher umschichten könnte.

The same applies to ITER, the same applies to questions of internal security, the same applies to major questions of research, the same applies to questions when I address areas of focus that the Parliament has, namely in the field of youth, education and research.
We are partly dealing with a lack of implementation. We are also partly dealing with a lack of transparency in the allocation of funds.
All these questions must be dealt with and processed concretely with each other and not answered by silence on the part of the Council.
Dear Commissioner Hahn, ladies and gentlemen, I have a problem with the way the debate is going.
If we talk about mountain islands and sparsely populated regions, then I get the impression from individual contributions that they are extraterritorial and directly subject to the European Union.
Aber so ist es ja nicht.
Each of these areas belongs to a member state that is sovereign.
And the implementation of European decisions and goals are still a matter for the Member States, according to the subsidiarity principle.

When I look at the European level, we have always paid special attention to these areas, mountain regions, sparsely populated areas, islands, in the Commission's communication up to the Lisbon Treaty.
And here in Parliament, too, many resolutions were adopted to support this region.

If I hear many complaints here that there are still grievances in the areas, then the question arises for me how have the Member States dealt with the impulses that we have sent from the European level?
Und was haben? Wie sind die Regionen selbst damit vorgegangen und haben die europäischen Fördermöglichkeiten genutzt?

Here a new strategy is being demanded. So we are already doing the officers of the DG REGIO light, who are supposed to incorporate the multitude of problems of islands, mountains and sparsely populated areas into a strategy.

At the same time, we are experiencing an inflation of strategies, Danube, Baltic Sea, Black Sea, climate change, and the like, more that we both need a strategy for the strategies so that we can still maintain an overview.

Dear colleagues, I think that's what it's all about, and that's what was said today, and I'm very grateful to Commissioner Hahn for mentioning it. We have to fight for a cohesion policy and a regional policy at the European level after 2013.
I think that is the focus of our work, and we should also convince our colleagues in Parliament that this will be the case.
And in a continuation of cohesion and regional policy beyond the year two thousand thirteen, mountains, islands, and the other areas will also find their place.
However, we should not get bogged down with individual resolutions on the subject, for which there is currently no occasion. Thank you very much.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, thank you to the colleagues who have worked so intensively on this project, especially to my colleague Bilal Quadras.
This is proof that European policy is capable of responding to crises and offering solutions that help.
We have had this supply security situation several times.
The problem of supply security has become clearer and clearer.
We were forced to act and we acted.

Wir haben Lösungen gefunden, die nicht einfach waren, die auch neue Instrumente bedeuten und die und das finde ich das Interessante daran eben nicht nur Infrastrukturstandards schaffen in Europa nicht nur gemeinsame Regeln für Präventions und Notfallpläne schaffen nicht nur die Gewissheit, wie der Kommissar eben.

Wir haben gezeigt, dass wir in Zukunft 30 Tage Sicherheit den Menschen anbieten können, sondern auch gezeigt, dass wir in der Lage sind, Kompromisse auszuloten, Kompromisse, die dann zu aktionsfähigen Lösungen führen.

The role of the companies is now in the spotlight, as they are responsible for building the networks. But the flexibility of the policy is also important, as it says we do not force things that in the end do not make sense and are not smart.

Wir wollen nicht mehr vernünftig sind also zum Beispiel die Flexibilität auch bei den Rückflüssen bei den notwendigen Rückflüssen aber nicht zu sagen über alles und immer und jeden Preis, sondern auch die Notwendigkeit oder die Möglichkeit, Einzelfälle beurteilen zu können, genauso wie die Zusammenarbeit im regionalen Bereich zu stärken.

And just as important, I believe, is the indication that Member States must also take their responsibility. But if the solutions cannot be found, the Commission is given an additional task. The Commission, which is strengthened, but which does not decide alone, but which then decides, if other solutions are no longer possible or which has the final say.
So flexibility, solutions that keep the burdens within manageable limits, but at least ensure that there are solutions, and that is the good news from Brussels for the people in Europe.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I do not need to emphasize how important cohesion and regional policy are for the coexistence and growth in Europe.
I believe, however, that the regional and cohesion policies of the future must also be increasingly focused on cities.
Because cities are an important engine in the development of Europe.
At the same time, however, they are currently experiencing particularly ecological, economic, and social problems.
Therefore, my very specific question to Commissioner Hahn, what possibilities do you see to highlight the urban dimension?

And I would wish that we would talk a little more honestly about it and then make a few fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that really move things forward.
This is more exhausting, more tiring will also mean conflict, but that is the meaning of democracy.

The consolidation of public budgets has so far focused solely on cutting expenditures.
The reduction of public spending primarily affects workers, pensioners and the poor, i.e. those who rely on the welfare state.
The revenue side of the public sector has been completely overlooked so far.
It is the second adjustment screw that can be turned to consolidate public budgets.
Above all, however, the main causes of the public debt crisis and the reduction of public debt can also be appropriately addressed through the revenue side.
For the consolidation of public budgets, an increase in tax revenue is simply indispensable.

In fact, the high debt of public budgets is mainly a consequence of the nationalization of private debts, namely the assumption of the debts of private banks and the financing of the consequences of the financial crisis by the public hand.
The responsibility for the debt crisis does not rest solely on the shoulders of the states.
It is therefore not only obvious, but also politically necessary to ask the financial sector to contribute.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally be involved in the repayment of these debts as the main cause of public debt.
This is an important political signal that this report conveys, if it is adopted in the way it has been presented.
But we also consider Eurobonds to be a sensible and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to debt reduction than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice.

Dear Madam President, Madam Commissioner Cruz, radio frequencies are a precious and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and consideration of the broader societal context.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the cultural diversity of Europe is an important asset that must be preserved and expanded in the future.
In order to make this possible, we must face the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the cultural and creative sector.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, but it also represents an important economic factor.
In the EU are about five million people employed in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to about two and a half percent of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that develops faster than many areas of the rest of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content that the cultural sector offers, as well as the way and quality of the content that has been changed and further developed by technology.
We therefore need framework conditions for the culture and creative industries that enable them to develop sustainably in the face of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
Culture and creative industry is a motor for Europe.
And that is why we must also pay attention to this area in the field of school and vocational education.
We must teach young people and also in the offerings of lifelong learning, cultural and creative skills.
However, we must also strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural creators and not only the entrepreneurial skills, but also a good media competence in the field of new technologies.
We need framework conditions in which cultural workers can secure their livelihood.

And that is why we will have to deal intensively with the issues of copyright, social security and the issues of intellectual property, but also of open access to information and content, in order to ensure the further development of the digital single market.

President, dear colleague Kellem, dear colleagues from the Baltic countries, dear colleagues, today we commemorate in a special way the expulsion and mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These expulsions are among the darkest events in European history.
In fact, the last century was not only and not least also and not too unjustly called a century of expulsions.
And we all bow to the victims of these inhuman actions today.
We demand, in this context, a complete clarification of Soviet history and, in particular, the crimes of Stalinism.

Today's Russia should not see this as a political attack, but as support for the re-examination of its own history, which, like the history of other European countries, is marked by both light and dark sides.
But as we think of the victims from the Baltic countries, we think of the Armenians, who were expelled from Turkey at the beginning of the last century.
We remember the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
A special highlight were the deportations in Europe in the middle of the century by the Nazi regime and by the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The expulsions after the Second World War also left deep scars, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslavian war.
However, we must not forget that many colonial powers were characterized by expulsions.
We must call for a serious debate on the various forms of evictions and the pretexts for them.
And this also includes the clarification of guilt and the punishment of the guilty, as far as this is still possible, as is now the case in the case of Mladić.
But the decisive answer is European unity, especially through and with the independent Baltic countries, and a clear commitment to continuing the still not completed European unification process.
This historical task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but especially to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many politicians from all countries of Europe, from East and West, have worked on it.
Let us think, for example, of the dancey statement signed by the Polish President Wroclaw and the German President Rau.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must be vigilant, even against the first approaches of expulsions, such as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all statements, such as the one that one should send the Arab immigrants back to the boats across the Mediterranean, and we must resist if some want to lift the achievements of Europe without borders again and return to a new, narrow-minded nationalism.
If we do not reject the fear of expulsion and deportation, but we wholeheartedly commit ourselves to the continuation of European unity as the only real guarantee against a

Politik, die im vergangenen Jahrhundert so viel Unglück über die Menschen in Europa, aber auch darüber hinaus ausgebracht hat, niemals vergessen niemals widerstanden Forderungen, die unmittelbar nach dem Zweiten Weltkrieg entstanden sind.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, I had the opportunity to witness the referendum on the independence of South Sudan as an observer of the parliament, and I was impressed by the great approval of the South Sudanese to determine the fate of their country in the future.
And I also saw the great expectation among the people who saw the independence of their country as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands of so-called internal displaced persons, who drove the decades-long struggles in the south into the refugee camps of the north, made their way to their former southern Sudanese homeland.

And of course, the people in South Sudan, in addition to the independence of the country, want to live in peace, above all, to go a path to a happier future after all the decades of war, in which millions of South Sudanese had to leave their lives.
On the ninth of July, the new state of South Sudan is set to officially become independent and expand the family of states in our world.
The starting conditions are extremely poor, and a lot has already been said about this here.
Seventy percent of the population lives as nomadic herders, eighty percent are illiterate. The conflict over Abyei is expanding into a military conflict.
There were already dead and wounded.

If that were not enough, the rivalries between the tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also increasing. According to observers, more than a thousand people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and the injured are hardly counted.
Sudan was already one of the failed states.
There is a danger that the state of South Sudan will begin as a failed state.
I am firmly convinced that there is a great obligation of Europe to these regions.
