Debates after the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogues now stand the vote on the political package, the great compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers on the future labelling of food.
This regulation is intended to provide the consumer with more and better information about food so that he can make a targeted purchasing decision.
But that's not all. The European food industry should also benefit.
Legal certainty, de-bureaucratisation and better enforcement are the goal.
This is especially important for small and medium-sized enterprises, and it should be known that the food sector in the European Union consists of over eighty percent of SMEs.
At the same time, this labeling must fit for every food and every non-alcoholic drink, from staple food to highly processed ready-made meals.
Therefore, a mandatory labeling in traffic light colors is not possible, because this labeling does not fit basic foodstuffs.
Despite all difficulties, despite all political ideological differences in Parliament, despite all national egoisms of the Member States, the now achieved compromise can be seen.
Allergens will be immediately recognizable.
The botanical origin of vegetable oils is indicated.
There is a country of origin marking for pork, poultry, sheep and goat meat.

For other products, a follow-up assessment will show whether and how the origin can be indicated, for example, for milk and dairy products single ingredients, i.e. products that consist of a main ingredient, meat in processed
Erzeugnissen et cetera. Imitates will on the front clearly have to be marked and the same applies to minced meat and for shaped fish put together glued together from small pieces.
A packaging should not give the impression that there is something inside that is not actually there.
If a picture of fruits is on a yogurt, there must also be fruits in it and not just dye and flavorings.
In addition, there is the mandatory disclosure of the most important nutrients always per 100 grams or 100 milliliters for reasons of comparability.
Added water in meat must be marked the date of the first freezing in meat and fish and many other details.
The most important thing, however, is that all information must be legible.

We have defined legibility, we have set a minimum font size, and the Commission has been tasked with establishing binding rules for other factors, such as the contrast between the font and the background.
At the same time, we protect the craft from too high costs and bureaucracy.
Unpackaged fresh products must provide allergen information, but not the complete nutritional information that can be determined by expensive analyses.
The Commission originally wanted this, but it would have destroyed the national and regional specialities and led to a European standard. That is why we prevented it.
But now we have all agreed and the serious consumer advocates are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

Thanks to the constructive cooperation of all shadow rapporteurs as well as many colleagues, we have succeeded in developing a consistent, comprehensive approach to improving road safety for the first time with this report.

It takes into account the contents of the UN Charter for Road Safety 2010 to 2020, as well as the contents and objectives of the traffic safety work of the EU Member States and broader circles of civil society.
It contains ambitious but realistic goals for the period up to twenty twenty and with the vision Serom for the period beyond.
By 2020, the number of accident fatalities is to be reduced by fifty percent, that of children by sixty percent, and that of the seriously injured by forty percent.
This is in the very best interest of every individual in our people, but also in our economy.
We recommend to the Member States to break down goals and methods on their territory and expect them to have their own traffic safety action programs.
It also contains, secondly, who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is by no means only the European Union.

In the context of subsidiarity, the holistic approach means that even member states, regional or municipal responsible companies, and even every individual road user, in the sense of their co-responsibility, have to take responsibility.
And it contains thirdly, how, i e with which instruments, activities and measures the goals are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at European level are only one strategy.
We can and want to do without guidelines, recommendations, and orders.
Special attention has been paid to subsidiarity. What does it mean that responsibilities and liabilities have been clearly named, even where they are shared?
We appreciate the Commission's diverse activities.

However, since they come from the most diverse general directions such as transport, economy, consumer protection, environment, communication, research and development, internal market and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes contradictory.
Therefore, we propose the appointment of a coordinator for road traffic safety within the European Commission.
This avoids the sustainable establishment of an agency for road safety, but greatly increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the choice of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically based approach based on comparable, high-quality data definitions and statistics.

We therefore call for, among other things, a harmonized analysis of the causes of injuries and accidents, as well as the EU-wide exchange of data while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six main fields of action were identified.
They concern the people as road users, the road traffic regulations, the vehicles, the infrastructure, their intelligent networking, and the special consideration of the weaker road users.

Yes, Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to make a few remarks on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have already done.
Instead of pushing a tax evasion barrier, which would be sensible, instead of plugging loopholes for tax evaders, a Swiss cheese with big holes has been produced here.

That foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is also sufficient that the assets buried in Switzerland are converted into foundation assets.
The corresponding forms are available in Swiss banks.
Some time ago, information about several tax evaders who hid their assets in Switzerland was added to the tax amnesty in Germany.
The agreement now grants these individuals amnesty and the tax authorities are no longer allowed to use the information they have on them.
What kind of agreement is this that puts tax collection on the line?
In a Swiss Bank advertisement, it is stated that, accordingly, in the future, customers will benefit even more from the values of the Swiss financial center due to this agreement.

This agreement obviously lacks not only the necessary vote at the EU level, but also the efforts of the EU to increase transparency in tax issues, to make tax collection more efficient in the Member States, and above all, to combat and prevent tax fraud.

Merkel gesagt hat aber eine Übergangsregierung alleine, die das finanzpolitische Notprogramm durchsetzt, kann nicht Zukunft haben, wenn es kein demokratiepolitisches Notprogramm gibt.

Thank you very much, Madam President, there is no doubt that this House stands for transparency and openness towards the citizen.

Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are ignored. The protection of competition procedures, sensitive and personal data is disregarded.

This includes largely confidential and secret documents as well as all related information.

Information from ongoing interinstitutional procedures, such as informal trilogue negotiations, would also have to be published.

It means public access to the proceedings. It means public influence on the decision-making process. Then we could just as well put the lobbyists at the table and let them negotiate. Does that really represent the citizen?

Oder würde es nicht vielmehr unsere Arbeit behindern?

Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, on such an important and comprehensive topic as the White Paper on the future of transport, the risk is always great that in the end you end up with a Christmas tree where everyone tries to put their two or three wish topics.

Further opening of cabotage in road transport only on the condition that social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.

So hätte ich mir eine Aussage zum Modellschiff gewünscht, wo mehr Verkehr von der Straße auf die Schiene und auf die Wasserwege gelegt würde.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it surprises me that we have to keep reminding ourselves what is actually meant by structural and cohesion policy.

The cohesion and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union, and it is intended to serve by definition the consolidation of economic and social cohesion in the community and to promote growth and employment in the underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of cohesion and structural policy has been proven, especially in the years of the crisis.
Many regions would find it even more difficult in terms of economic development if these funds were not available.

The implementation of the Structural Fund is carried out on the basis of operational programmes. It has already been pointed out that the funding strategy of the respective region is described in them.
European Union, Member States and regions work here in partnership and create such a true European added value.
The success of cohesion and structural policy also depends on the reliability of the programs and the available and available funds.

Therefore, it surprises me very much when, again and again, from member states, but also from the Commission side, as we are now seeing, attempts are made to use the Structural Funds as a savings account for all possible current policy initiatives.

This is not in line with the purpose of cohesion policy and also undermines the actors in the regions who are already working on the basis of long-term strategies and contracts to achieve their goals.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and promoting economic growth are important goals.

Das wird aber nur erreicht werden, wenn die partnerschaftliche Zusammenarbeit zwischen den Regionen, den Mitgliedstaaten und der Kommission beibehalten wird und die Akteure in den Regionen einbezogen werden und bleiben.
Because only they have the knowledge about what needs to be done in their regions.
The cohesion and structural policy is the unifying, partnership-based, solidarity-based thread of action between the individual levels of politics in the European Union.
In it, the solidarity Europe becomes visible on the ground in the regions and it should not be easily abandoned due to political quick shots.

We ourselves, dear colleagues, are also called upon to do something to ensure that the governments that have been blocking so far have to give up this attitude.
Ich denke, das ist auch ein Stück Selbstverpflichtung für uns.
Dear colleague Dole, I have listened to you attentively.
What you propose, to provide for a growth test for all expenditures in parallel with the subsidiarity test, means to narrow the goals to growth.

It is generally known that the economy does not give birth to children who do not grow up and cannot provide them with a life in an intact nature.
This speaks in favor of the priorities being changed by the Commission and also by the Council, that they are reconsidered.
Wir werden als Fraktion sehr genau prüfen, ob das, was Sie heute früh vorgelegt haben, tatsächlich einer Prioritätenänderung entspricht.
So far, the motto was first the economy, which needs functioning financial markets.
And that was the first step, to sanitize the public finances, i.e. to reduce the debt and to keep the markets calm.
And Mr. Dole, who is unfortunately not present, I would actually just like to say I would hold it just as Georges Marchais would.
I did not understand his answer, but I would contradict him.
I think the measures that have been introduced were just wrong.
They were not right, it was not right to focus exclusively on the economic recovery and to completely ignore what was happening to the people.
It was not right to put the stability of the euro above everything else and to say that we don't care what happens to people.
It has to be the other way around. First, it's about the people, then we can talk about further euro stabilization.

The speculative attacks on Spain brought the interest rates for Spanish government bonds to over six percent and thus also close to the interest rate levels at which other countries such as Greece, Portugal or Ireland have taken up the support of the rescue fund.
And here also from the EU, from the ECB and also from the IMF, the member state-imposed austerity policy with the drastic reduction of all kinds of public spending from.
The reduction of wages and pensions, the increase of value added taxes and much more has burdened the citizens and has not prevented the new spiral.
Rigorous reduction of state spending exacerbates the decline, driving up the debt ratio of states, and this must be our common understanding.
If Mr Draghi recently said that the European social model is at the end, then I am happy, Mr Barroso, if you say no, we in the Commission do not think so.
Then I also expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece and to Portugal, to Ireland, and to register exactly what is happening there.
What happens to the people who are currently fighting for their survival?
What happens or what do we do together so that this suicide spiral that has been set up, especially in the most affected debt countries, is finally interrupted?
It cannot be that we are watching here inaction.
And we do not need social political programs that will intervene at some point when other measures have been taken.
We must act now. Where have your objectives from the 2020 strategy for combating poverty been?
What has become of the European poverty platform?
She has been put aside.
Das war vor der Krise.
But now, in the middle of the crisis, people need help. They need support, and they need the action of the European Union.
Sie brauchen keine leeren Versprechungen.
We need concrete ideas about what should be done now.
If you do that, you will get the support of my group.
Do you support all those who have also recognized the signs of the times within the Commission and want to change things?
But please don't just keep going and say it will be fine.
It will be nothing more if it continues like this. I demand that you present a concrete project, a concrete program, on how we can really actively help the people in the affected countries now.
Do something about it.
We will have to do it in our countries, so that the funds for the ESF 2013 or 2014 to 2020 or even for the other programs are not cut.
Dass die Mitgliedstaaten ihren Verantwortungen nachkommen.
Dear colleagues, the current situation of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a tax policy fairy tale.

Weil einige Länder gegen weitere Steuerkooperation sind.

Aber etwas zu tun ist immer noch besser als gar nichts zu unternehmen.
And extraordinary situations sometimes require extraordinary measures.

The budget and debt crisis in some states led to an extraordinary situation in which important projects and measures in the field of cohesion and structural policy can no longer be carried out, because the banking sector is no longer financially viable and private investors are no longer available.
I see an extraordinary measure in the present proposal for the creation of risk allocation instruments for the further financing of projects in structural policy.
Funds from cohesion and structural policy that are available to countries that want to use these instruments of division can be used for the financial protection of ongoing projects.
I am very grateful to the rapporteur, Danuta Hübner, for her contribution to the clarification of the Commission proposal and for clearly stating when and how these instruments should be used.
I am also of the opinion that these risk-sharing instruments should only be due to the current situation and should not be prejudicial to the future funding period.
The amendment to the biometric passport regulation of 2009, which was requested to carry out a review after three years and to present four studies, was supported by our faction.
And that is also because it has repeatedly raised serious concerns for data protection reasons and also because of the overestimation of the use of biometric data in passports.
The belief in the perfect identification, the overestimation of this means and what results from it, the underestimation of other members of the security chain, are really problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this great mistake, namely the assumption that they are immutable and most trustworthy.
And that is not the case.
Auch diese Daten sind veränderbar im Verlaufe des Lebens.
In children, they look different from in old age.
And that is why reliable and serious studies and final conclusions are necessary.
Fälschung wird trotzdem fleißig.
Ich habe mir nun feststellen können.
Wie es vorkommen muss in Großbritannien und in anderen Ländern immer wieder belegen die Chips sind überhaupt nicht sicher gegen Missbrauch.
They are happily cracked and can mean permanent damage for those affected.
The standards within the EU are also extremely diverse.
The error rate is very, very high, as in France and the Netherlands.
And again and again, the question must be asked what we use biometric data for when documents are forged and in circulation.
If one link in the chain is forged, biometric data will not help us if the original documents are inconsistent.
One last thing, the Chaos Computer Club in Germany only took a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

To do this, the friends from the Chaos Computer Club needed the lid of a plastic bottle, a superglue, a digital camera, and a bit of wood glue. In a few minutes, they had cracked the chip. So much for supposed security.
Wir erwarten von der Kommission die Vorlage der Studien und natürlich auch die Ergebnisse und die Konsequenzen, die sich daraus ableiten. Danke.
Dear Council, the Commission is unfortunately not represented sufficiently today, as I would have liked to see in respect for the Parliament.

I believe that we must indeed work together with the asylum support office and the Greek authorities to identify more quickly which people who have come to Greece could actually be.

Also in andere Länder der Europäischen Union überführt werden, weil sie erstens definitiv nie mehr in ihr Heimatland zurückkehren können und weil sie zweitens unter Umständen auch Potenzial und Qualifikationen mitbringen, die für alle Sinn und zielführend sein können.

Those who are to be returned to their home country, who have neither qualifications nor qualifications, to stop in Greece or the European Union, because they would actually have a chance to stay in their own home countries.
Thank you very much, Mr President, Mr Minister, Mrs Commissioner, and also the rapporteur for her always very committed and exemplary work.
I can share much of the criticism that Sophie in 't Veld has expressed, support it or have supported it in part.
But there always comes the point at which one must take responsibility.
And for the EPP or for myself, I therefore also claim that we must now deal with the realities and not be able to retreat to ideological or theoretical positions.
Fact is, the USA have been collecting this PNR data for ten years and there was not a single complaint.
The fact is that we all do not want the data traffic to be stopped, even if we have an opposing attitude, that we can stop the data traffic at all.
You had just performed it.

And the fact is, in my opinion, that the legal services have all expressed to us orally that this agreement is better than the other agreement, than the alternatives.

Responsibility for the citizens, which would otherwise be left alone and with less protection and rights.
Responsibility for the airlines, which would otherwise be left in absolute legal uncertainty, as the Commissioner had also explained.
Responsibility, but also for the EU as a contracting party in questions of data protection and security, and also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Mr Commissioner. The explanations you have given us were very detailed.

Numbers sometimes speak louder than big words. And until today, the European Parliament, as you have mentioned, has issued almost two thousand patents on plants and almost two hundred patents on animals, which have been created with and without the use of genetic engineering.
Two outstanding examples I would like to mention the granting of patents for genetically modified and selectively bred barley. This applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
Our farmers, as well as our producers and consumers, are therefore affected.
And this example, in my opinion, shows an enormous extent of patenting.
Second example, the so-called long-life tomato, not to be confused with their long-life oil, which they have in their diesel engines.
With this trick of the US company Arcadia, this patent was circumvented by the valid EU rules.
The patent is not the tomato variety, but its genetic material, specifically selected enzymes.

This shows what tricks are being used here, and although, as you say, Commissioner, in the Biopatent Directive of nineteen ninety-eight in Article four, clip and claw are not patentable, plant varieties and animal breeds A and B are in the essentially biological process of breeding plants or animals.
We believe that this definition must be specified. It must be laid out more precisely.
Technical procedures that are used to support conventional breeding should not lead to patentability as a whole.
We say no patent for life.
And we need a clear signal here for more ethics and for more honesty in dealing with creation, once again against patentability of life throughout Europe.
Therefore, Commissioner, we demand the clear statement of the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources in Europe are prohibited and remain so.
Secondly, we demand a clear position on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive No patent on life.
And thirdly, Commissioner, we demand on behalf of many farmers in Europe a clear definition of the privilege of farmers and farmers in the entire legislation. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Madam Chair. I would like to take a position on the release of Europol and Eurojust.
To Europol here is little is actually nothing to complain about.
The year-end balance sheet reflects the financial situation in 2010 in all essential aspects, and all underlying transactions are in compliance with the regulations and therefore also lawful.
Only the high transfers in relation to the actually low incurred costs are striking.
Europol attributes this to the move to a new headquarters. This is of course understandable.
But Europol agrees to take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
In addition, Europol wants to commit to monitoring the implementation of the budget plan on a monthly basis from two thousand twelve.
I recommend that we follow through with this, even if it really happens.
Against this background, I recommend the relief of Europol.
Zu Eurojust. Here also reflects the end of the year in all essential aspects the financial situation in two thousand ten again.
All transactions are also legal and compliant here.
But here, too, high operating expenses were transferred to the year two thousand eleven.
According to Eurojust, this was mainly due to an organizational structure project, a new computer infrastructure and costs in connection with data processing.
It is announced that all of this will be improved in the future, including better compliance with tender requirements.
I recommend that we also check this in the future and above all to check whether all open positions are actually filled in the future.
Das ist verbessert worden.
Aber wenn diese Stellen nicht bald besetzt werden, dann mussten wir fast überlegen, Mittel zu streichen, und das wäre negativ für Orio.
Ich empfehle dennoch Entlastung.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what must worry us and put us in panic is not the sheer number of young people unemployed in Europe alone, but the development.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of unemployed youth increased by 26.5 percent. This is according to the International Labour Organization.
It is this development that urgently requires measures. We are not only disconnecting an entire generation from the job market, we are disconnecting an entire generation from a livable future.
If we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we need not be surprised that young people turn away from this EU because they have no reasonable prospects for work and life.

Mr. Commissioner, I urgently request that you ensure that decisive countermeasures are initiated. I already recognize a lot, but please ensure that the long-standing spiritual calm does not now turn into operational chaos.

If I read that the Commission is starting a program after young people, when they apply abroad, are now also to be financially supported, then we are organizing a traveling circus, because that does not solve the problem.
And on the contrary, it becomes counterproductive. Technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff are then recruited by the states that are richer, which are not in this crisis.
It now needs in this crisis the cause for this development is offensive measures, namely the dismantling of this savings warning, which affects the economy in Europe.
We need a targeted growth policy, we need a strengthening of domestic purchasing power, public investments in education, research, alternative energy.
That would be the way.
With the combination of European funding, it would then be possible to actually develop an integrated concept that gives young people a perspective on life.
Last remark With this youth unemployment, there is also no objection to wanting to raise the retirement age for people to seventy.
We need a different policy that provides young people with access to the labour market.
Darum bitte ich dringend danke.
Madam colleague, you have just said that everything that would speak for the financial transaction tax is speculation, and then you came up with very speculative examples yourself.

I would like to know from you what you think of these investigations by the Commission and the Study Commission, which very clearly states that the real economy has been included much too little in their dependence on.

The financial markets, i.e. ninety five percent of the companies, are by no means dependent on the money collection of it and that one can very well turn a negative growth effect, of which one has spoken so far, into a positive one by making appropriate growth-promoting public investments.
Ist das für Sie auch nur Spekulation oder würden Sie sagen, dass eine so fundierte, breit angelegte Studie der Kommission schon auch ihre Berechtigung hat und ein starkes Argument darstellt?

Thank you very much. Yes, colleagues, the financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been the subject of discussion for many years. But I think it takes up essential elements of the Tobin tax.
She at least accepts the idea of involving the financial markets in taxation, taxing them, and above all, involving them in the costs of the crisis.
I think this is a very important signal to the financial markets.
This is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.
There were a whole series of actions, petitions, written undertakings to politicians to finally introduce a financial transaction tax at European level.
I think the Parliament has achieved great success with the majority that is here for this report, for this tax.
Certainly it is not enough to stabilize and limit the financial markets as might be necessary, but I think it is a really important step that has been taken here.
I would like to appeal to the Council to take the voices of the citizens, voters and voters seriously and to advocate for them.
That there will be a real introduction, that the introduction of this tax will not be blocked in the Council due to the British position or other positions.
I think it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I think it is a great responsibility.

It is now up to the Council to take action here, and I would like to use my speaking time to appeal to the Council to do everything possible to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality. Thank you.
Liebe Kolleginnen, liebe Kollegen, ich denke, bei allen Detailproblemen, über die man ja reden kann und über die im weiteren Gesetzgebungsverfahren auch noch zu reden ist, sollten wir uns über eines.
The financial markets cannot function according to the model if everything goes well, the banks are writing down profits, and if something goes wrong, taxpayers are holding the blame.
And that is why it makes sense to subject financial transactions to tax as well.
Und es macht Sinn, das grenzüberschreitend zu tun.

In Europa oder zumindest in der Eurozone werden wir nicht Verwerfungen haben, sondern wir werden dauerhaft einen Beitrag dazu leisten, einen stabilen Finanzplatz zu bekommen, der das generiert, wofür Finanzplätze eigentlich vorgesehen sind, nämlich dass die Unternehmen

Zugang zu Kapital haben, dass der Sparer Möglichkeiten hat, etwas wegzusparen oder für die Altersvorsorge auf die Seite zu bringen und dass damit die Finanzmärkte wieder die Aufgabe erfüllen, für die sie einmal geschaffen wurden, nämlich einen Mehrwert für die Realwirtschaft zu leisten.
All that drove us into the financial crisis were products that did not create any value for the real economy.

Deswegen macht es Sinn, über eine Steuer einen Beitrag dazu zu leisten, dass dies hoch bestraft wird, dass dies sanktioniert wird, dass dies gesteuert wird, in dem Sinne, dass Kapital wieder seine Aufgabe erfüllt.
And that is why I am campaigning for this proposal today with a large majority.
Thank you very much. The reform of the general preference system was necessary.
It is now good that there are longer terms and that there is more security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too vague, as the Committee on Development has already said.
The Commission unfortunately only refers to the classification of world banks.
In the past, the Parliament has repeatedly dealt very critically with the gross domestic product as the only criterion.
The definition of countries with high middle income can refer to countries with a gross domestic product of four thousand or up to twelve thousand dollars.
So there is a huge and far too large range of tension, and it does not correspond to the realities on the ground in any way.
We certainly do not find it problematic that countries such as Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are able to find a way out.
The reform in this respect was so good.
Aber diese Länder sind sowieso Hoheinkommensländer.
Russia and China are countries with high middle incomes, over which we certainly do not have to worry about falling out of the APS.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer countries, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
So far, the Commission has at least also included the vulnerability criterion, i e countries that export little or only very little goods.
This at least avoids the fact that countries that are less dependent on exports and are very, very vulnerable have been rated too highly.
Why did the Commission then delete this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, the Fijian Islands, Gabon and Botswana will thus fall out, although their economies fall under the criterion of vulnerability.
Why didn't the Commission continue the old criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate?
There is a suspicion that the Commission wants to force poorer countries into free trade agreements that are even less favorable for them.

The preference system is, however, an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development path of a country or region no longer plays any role at all.
Fortunately, however, there will still be the opportunity for colleagues in the plenary to vote for our amendment, which includes vulnerability as a criterion.
The new regulation also leads to the disintegration of trading regions.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
The Commission should instead of individual countries, take into account development regions more strongly.
Here, too, we Greens have tabled an amendment that we hope will find much support.
And it is also problematic if countries that yesterday still benefited from the APS should fall out of the program overnight.
Transition periods must be and that a few months are not enough for economic development, we see in our own countries.

Ultimately, we Members of Parliament must also consider whether we want to focus on speed in all legislative projects and then work with one-sided compromises, or whether we would rather involve the entire plenary.

I believe that for legislation, the entire parliament is important, for democracy as well, and not the time and not the speed is important, but it takes time and democracy to implement and to pass laws properly. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr President, Madam High Representative. I was also a member of the election observation commission of the European Parliament in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to see with how much hope and expectation the people stood at the polling stations and waited to cast their vote.
We know today that these expectations were not met.
Although the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were not fair and also not democratic.
We must address this offensively, as colleague Nedelčeva also did in her report.
The former president Joseph Kabila has been declared the winner. The opposition is suppressed.
In the east of the country, the violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have flared up again, and it is unclear whether third countries such as Rwanda are involved.
In any case, the civilian population is the most suffering, which can no longer live in peace and quiet for decades.
The country's wealthiest are swept up in a swamp of corruption. The Congo remains in all international evaluations at one of the last places.

The international community, especially the European Union, with its possibilities, must increase the pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow real democracy in his country. At the next regional elections, he will have the opportunity.

Dazu und dass die kongolesische Armee nicht auch noch die Zivilbevölkerung drangsaliert, sondern international gesuchte Verbrecher gegen die Menschlichkeit wie Bosco und DRC endlich ergreift und einem Gericht zuführt. Und.
International should all states finally commit to not delivering any more weapons to the Congo.
Without pressure from outside, the human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Colleagues, the two-pack should create further access rights against crisis countries in the eurozone.
The European Semester, which was created as a framework for a necessary and better coordination of financial and economic policy, should be given teeth.
According to the Commission's will, Member States should be forced to accept financial aid.
With the six-pack, far-reaching sanction options have already been created that can be imposed on euro states with financial problems.
The European Semester is already perceived by citizens as more of a democracy reduction than a meaningful economic policy coordination instrument.
At the same time, the German government openly threatens Greek citizens with expulsion from the Eurozone if they make the wrong choice in Sunday's election.
Why don't we stop with these humiliating and undemocratic threats?

In a situation in which the euro crisis has once again dramatically escalated, I think of Spain, of Cyprus, does it not further bring us member states into the crisis, which are in the crisis, to the brink?
We should finally develop solutions. The report authors of the two Pex have developed quite sensible approaches to this.
Of Eliza Ferrera, the reference to the redemption fund would be a worthwhile and sensible measure to combat debt.
But also the proposal of Jean Paul Gaultier, a structured state bankruptcy.
Central is, however, that Europe undertakes a joint and solidarity effort to bring the eurozone back on a growth path.
The strong countries in Europe must stop showing themselves satisfied with their finger on their partner countries.
You have to start doing your homework and investing in growth and taking responsibility.
The one-sided austerity policy of the Merkel era has failed miserably as a crisis solution.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in June two thousand ten the Heads of State or Government of the EU finally realized that the European Community needs a better coordinated financial and economic policy.
At the summit, you invented the European Semester, so to speak.
It is absolutely correct that the members of a monetary union should not be allowed to look only at how their policies affect companies, workers and consumers in their own country.
Eine europäische Perspektive ist nötig.

A single market without coordination in economic policy, wages, and social policy puts the Member States at risk of a great temptation, namely, to create short-term growth and job opportunities at the expense of their neighbours.
Such imbalances can lead the monetary union to economic and political collapse.
And it is exactly such a situation that the EU is currently facing.

The German economy has dug up the water from the neighbors over the years. No impulses through investments and wage growth. Instead, Berlin has driven the Eurozone almost to ruin with a decade of aggressive export policy.
Therefore, it is pleasing that the Commission is now slowly addressing this core problem of the euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and making appropriate recommendations.

The Federal Republic is rightly called upon to invest more in education, research, and childcare, and the Commission is rightly called upon to stop the abuse of mini-jobs and to adjust the wage increase to the productivity growth.
This is a late but important realization.
And I hope, Commissioner Rehn, that you will vigorously represent this demand against the German government, even if there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the Commission, especially Commissioner Barnier, for the very simple reason that the experience from the last legislative period before 2009

"War, dass mit Ausnahme eines ganz kurzen Erweckungsmomentes als der Vorschlag der europäischen Privatgesellschaft kam, der Vorgänger von Herrn Kommissar Barnier, Herr Kommissar McCreevy, das Gesellschaftsrecht eigentlich einen tiefen Schlaf hat, schlafen lassen und wie in diesen fünf Jahren dieser wichtigen Frage, die auch für den Binnenmarkt von Bedeutung ist, nicht."
The following are the key points of the discussion.
That has changed fundamentally, thank God.

Meanwhile, there are a number of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group that has dealt with the question of the further development of civil law, and we now have a consultation that we are of course also dealing with in Parliament.
The legal committee has decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report requires additional time and of course is also a little more detailed.

We have chosen the means of oral inquiry to the Commission in order to be able to discuss this issue with the Commission, with Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time to make our position on the Parliament clear in a subsequent resolution as to what should happen now.
I believe that it is necessary, similar to what we had about ten years ago, to develop a new action plan for European social law, and for many reasons.
There are gaps within European social law, real gaps that basically lead to the fact that the internal market is not created.
I would like to give the example of the missing fourteenth directive on seat relocation, which is in my opinion a typical example of such a gap.
The Parliament has twice in the legislative initiative reports demanded that concrete proposals from the European Commission be put on the table.
There is also the expert panel that the European Commission itself has appointed, which also expressed the same opinion.
It is simply one of the fundamental freedoms in the internal market that a company must be able to move in the internal market with regard to its registered office.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

Against this background, however, I must also criticize at the same time that the previous statement of the European Commission on the subject of the fourteenth directive actually remains far behind the expectations of the Parliament and, in our opinion, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
We are confident that, in the course of further work, if it comes to the action plan, this proposal will hopefully be found in the action plan.
Another important point in corporate law is the question of the further development of corporate law with the aim of reducing burdens for companies.
We already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example on the subject of.
Accounting. But I believe that there is also more to do and other aspects that will now also be clarified within the framework of the consultation.
Here we also expect further proposals from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the issue of the European private sector, which is currently hanging in the Council.
If there are individual member states in the EU that, due to a lack of their own decision-making power, are not able to resolve the deadlock on their own.

Europa voranzubringen, dann muss man hier eben wie bei anderen Vorhaben wie beim Patent oder beim Familienrecht auch mal darüber nachdenken, das Instrument der verstärkten Zusammenarbeit zu nutzen, damit zumindest alle anderen Europäer die Möglichkeit haben, in den Genuss dieser Möglichkeit zu kommen.
I would ask the Commission to think more deeply about this issue.
Another open problem is the question of applicable law, i.e. a kind of Rome Convention for cross-border problems in civil law.
Ich meine auch, dass diese Frage einer weiteren Untersuchung und Erörterung bedarf, und würde die Kommission bitten, dies zu tun.
And this is also closely related to the fact that.
Das Insolvenzrecht aber da ist ja ohnehin angekündigt, dass wir in absehbarer Zeit einen konkreten Vorschlag von Seiten der Europäischen Kommission bekommen werden.
You see, in civil law there is a lot to do.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken the initiative again and that it is clear that we will get significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can then also represent progress in the design of the internal market.
Das Parlament unterstützt dies im Grundsatz und im Ansatz.
Über die Details wird man sich natürlich noch und da müssen werden wir sicherlich.
Aber deshalb war sehr danke an die Kommission.
And of course, we would be happy if the Commission would actually pick up our initiatives and turn them into concrete proposals. Thank you.
Dear Commissioner, I highly appreciate your proposal regarding the productivity-oriented wage policy.
But in matters of minimum wage, you have snubbed Mrs. Merkel and the question of employment in the health care sector, I do not believe you.

Madam President, many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not have any remaining disabilities if only they had received professional medical help within the first so-called golden hour after their accident.
We are a whole step closer to the vision zero.
The eCall system we are discussing today cannot prevent accidents. It is also not exempt from the obligation to provide assistance.
It only serves to automatically inform a call center in the event of a serious accident.
This must also be done to avoid abuse and overload due to minor accidents, to establish linguistic contact with the accident vehicle.
Only when the emergency call is confirmed or no one answers, emergency doctors equipped with a few but life-saving pieces of information are sent to the accident site.
The responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies with the Member States.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system sleeps, so it also does not send any signals or data and is not located.
It is also far superior to a mobile phone in terms of data protection.
Only with the automatic, sensor-controlled activation or the conscious, manual triggering does the system become active.
It then sends a minimum agreed set of data of information to a rescue control center.
Uniform standards and specifications across Europe will ensure that this data is recognized as an emergency, evaluated, and processed upon arrival.
Therefore, the Member States must also upgrade and expand their rescue service chains accordingly.

We want this eCall emergency call system to be based on the EU's uniform emergency number one one two, to be free for the user, to work everywhere in the EU, and to be compatible with the emergency call systems of neighboring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable, technology-neutral, open system architecture.
Through this, other intelligent public transport services such as real-time traffic information or availability of parking spaces can also be offered later.

Dear colleagues, I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements in the European Union. However, I also know that the borders of a country are always a very sensitive issue for our member states and will always remain so.
I am aware that the problems that exist between the Member States in relation to Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
And there are various problems.
And by ignoring, you do not make the problems better and you do not solve them better.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and no one here would even think of closing the border just because we have problems.
But I also ask the Commission for support in this area, not for restrictions and instructions.
The Schleyer Affair has been anchored because we want to ensure security while maintaining freedom of movement.
And if we carry out the Schleyer operation with success, namely at the borders, also to the Czech Republic, where one or the other drug dealer not only in a few cases, but in many.
If refugees try to get a foothold, then I think it is good when the German Federal Minister of the Interior and the Czech Minister meet to solve the problems that exist on the border together.
And then the Commission should not act in a regulatory way, but positively, with support, accordingly.

We want to keep the populists in check, but we also want to solve the real problems together. Therefore, I also ask the Council to work together with Parliament to find a solution so that we can successfully pass the Schengen dossiers, so that we have freedom of movement and at the same time ensure the security of citizens.
Thank you. The cases of disproportionate border controls listed by the Parliament in its question also show why the Council wants to leave the Parliament out in Schengen.
The Council wants to continue to undermine freedom of movement without the involvement of Parliament or without any form of parliamentary control or any form of public.
No wonder, then, that you prefer to sit on your hands away from uncomfortable questions in back rooms.

No wonder that the German government, without evaluation, wants to completely exclude an evaluation of the internal borders and thus does not want to see how much the freedom of movement is restricted.
Schengen does not belong to governments, but to the people of Europe, and therefore also belongs to the European Parliament. Thank you very much.

Dear Mr. President of the Council of the European Union, Mr. Dimitris Christofias, it is a special moment for me today and for my group to be able to welcome you here in your function as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also pleased that for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person at the top of the EU is someone we consider to be part of our political family.
Sie übernehmen die Präsidentschaft zu einem Zeitpunkt, da die Europäische Union vor Risiken Herausforderungen steht, und es sind die Weichen zu stellen, ob die Europäische
Union actually have a future or whether it will prove itself, and that would be a historical defeat, as a footnote in history.

have prepared the Presidency excellently and that they are also aware of this magnitude of their task.

I have long missed in official speeches that it is said that it is about the people, it is about those who are not responsible for the fact that we are in this crisis, but who have to bear the brunt of the most.

Hier hat sich etwas verdreht.

And the European Union must not simply be used as an instrument or spokesperson for a small, specific group in the population, or to present itself in this way.

And one last point, which I would also like to address, in order to emphasize that everything that you have mentioned in your priorities is important to us, and that we will also support the points that go in this direction, as I have just defined them.

To this one must say the Parliament has already demanded this with a broad majority two years ago.

With the decision of the Council that the ECB should be the place of the Eurozone supervisor, however, some difficulties are associated.
In the Council, this leads to unanimity and results in the Parliament not being involved in the decision-making process for this issue.
According to the experience with the supervision package, this is not acceptable.

And that is why it is important that we work quickly here, but that we also negotiate this proposal for changes in the ECB with the necessary changes to the existing supervisory regime as a package, and thus factually establish the principle of the democratic participation of the Parliament.
Demographically, there are also further challenges.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has no tasks so far.

If you are now responsible for banking supervision, the Parliament needs full budgetary rights, full control rights, questioning rights, appointment rights, and I am sure that the Parliament will also assert these in a broad majority.

The complicated questions beyond that, in the internal market, in consumer protection and in the balance between European power and financial responsibility, we will have to discuss thoroughly in the coming weeks. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Madam President. The new directive creates a basis for dealing with books, newspapers, works of art, films, musical pieces, TV productions, which are protected by copyright law, but for which the rights holder cannot be identified or can be identified.
Accordingly, books, films, photos, or other intellectual creations for which no rights holder can be found should also be made available to the public.
Und so wird ein kultureller Schatz gehoben.
For us in the Committee on Culture, it was particularly important to highlight the special significance of the diversity of the cultural heritage of the European Union in this legislative initiative.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishers, broadcasting institutions there are countless unused works. And just because the rights of the owners are not known, they should not be available to be made available so far.
This will change with the directive.
It enables the use of this cultural property in the future, provided that a careful search is conducted before its publication.
This is a very important point, so that it is not easily said that we do not find the rights holder.
Because a balance had to be found between the real rights of the creators of works and the need for the public to be able to use such works where the legal situation is not clear.
A special focus for us is also that we had to ensure that both known and unknown rights holders are fully protected.
And where the rights holders cannot be found, the draft makes the use of the digitization of the works possible.
Projects like European and other large European digitalization projects, but also our museums, archives and educational institutions as well as public broadcasting will be affected.
In the future, however, it will also be necessary to open the works in the archives of private publishers to the public.
This directive proposal and the compromise that has now been found is, in my eyes, also really a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the cultural treasure that is hanging there holds enormous potential.
And we should continue to work on this in the revision of the directive in two years. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think that with today's debate on MiFID, we are entering the core area of financial market regulation.
In dieser Legislaturperiode vorangetrieben sind, geht es doch darum, die Finanzmärkte zu regulieren und nicht nur einzelne Produkte zu betrachten, wie wir es in der Vergangenheit gemacht haben.
I just want to name a few keywords.
We didn't make working together very easy last year.

We have held a hearing in the committee. We have conducted a survey of all stakeholders, all interested groups, and based on that, we have worked out a result with various processes, working documents and the like, which we will present to the plenary for a vote today and tomorrow.
I would like to pick out a few points.
Topic number one market structure.

Wir müssen auf der einen Seite natürlich schon feststellen, dass sich in den letzten Jahren im Bereich der Finanzmärkte einiges getan hat, dass es unser Interesse aber als Parlament ist, dass jeder Handel von Finanzpapieren, der stattfindet, innerhalb der Mifid Spielregeln stattfindet, deswegen wir auch unter vielen Bedingungen einer neuen Kategorie.

Die sogenannten organized trading facilities zugestimmt haben, wo nur non equities gehandelt werden sollen, wo Eigenhandel verboten sein soll und wo gemäß Ausführung in Bezug auf Ausführung und Transaktion und Interaktion der Kunden eine entsprechende Ausführung nach eigenem Ermessen stattfinden kann.
Ich denke, dass wir damit einen wichtigen Beitrag dazu leisten, dass der ganze Bereich von OTC-Papieren, die gehandelt werden, innerhalb der Mifid-Welt gehandelt wird.
Another major issue that was not yet taken into account in the last MIFID is the so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.

Here, too, our goal was to establish clear rules of the game, to ensure that this area, which can be very dangerous, which can also be used manipulatively, is subject to strict regimes with minimum holding periods.

Trade interruption options with the possibility of testing algorithms with the possibility of supervisory structure algorithms to look at themselves with the introduction of a so-called tick size regime, a minimum price size and through corresponding fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of the warm period markets.

I believe that we have a special responsibility when it comes to limiting the speculative share in futures markets in such a way that we do not contribute to the wrong regulations that prevent people in the third and fourth world from being able to buy food anymore.
We have therefore chosen a two-part approach with the aim of curbing speculation but not harming the real economy.
With position limits with strict upper limits for the number of contracts or positions we want to achieve this.
We want to ensure that those who can prove that they really need a product with a so-called position check system do not suddenly also intervene speculatively in this market.
Another topic that concerns us very much is the area of investor protection.
I would just like to point out that we have chosen a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer and investor protection.
It is about identifying the needs of certain customer groups.
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex papers.

It is about defining appropriate products for target groups, carrying out product tests, telephone recordings, appropriate consultations, disclosure obligations, but and I will also indicate this very briefly in the area of provisions, to make subsidiarity.
Und die Mitgliedstaaten sollen gemäß ihrer Strukturen die Möglichkeit haben, entsprechende Anpassungen vorzunehmen.
Ich denke, da sind wir auf dem richtigen Weg.
After my time is up, I would like to thank everyone who has contributed to this.
I think it's a shame that you get only four minutes of speaking time for such a difficult topic.
I would like to thank all the colleagues who have worked with the Commission for their very constructive role in the last few weeks and months.

And I hope that we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council tomorrow with a strong vote from the plenary and to be able to conclude this important matter as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, thank you very much for the overall good cooperation on this report.
We have been able to further improve a Commission proposal at central points, which has already taken big steps in the right direction.
In the area of market structures, there will be more transparency, there will be more comprehensive transparency, especially in the area of derivative trading.

Within the framework of the MIFID, the decisions in the area of high-frequency trading of our compromise go much further than what the Commission originally proposed and deserve the support of the Parliament as a whole.
Und auch bei den Themen, die große öffentliche Kritik hervorgerufen haben, zeigt der Bericht in die richtige Richtung.

In the area of commodity and food speculation, after big and difficult debates, that must also be said, is now much stronger than the Commission's decisions, because position limits are now written down as binding.
However, we still need further changes in this area to close gaps.
And I also hope for additions through the plenary vote and finally in the trilogue.
And it is pleasing that Mr Barnier has already signalled his support for the Parliament's further proposal.
Where the report, however, has weaknesses is in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the opportunity to ban products, which is a progress, but we still have no changes in the area of provision-driven advice.
The sale of financial products is still not primarily oriented towards the interests of customers, but is strongly dominated by the product that has the most commissions.
Especially in Germany, but everywhere in the EU, consumers have lost a lot of money.
Think of the open real estate funds.
For the citizens, for example in France, in Italy, in Spain, in Germany, will not change very much even after our compromise.
The basic principle will continue to be a provision orientation.
To refer to subsidiarity here is a bit simple.
Here I would have liked stronger rules.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, yes, what takes a long time, finally becomes good, I can only say.
The report on the approval of vehicles of the L category has ultimately become a good report.
The work took longer than we all thought, and especially than we had hoped. And there were many more pitfalls than we would have liked.
But at this point, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr van de Kamer, once again for the truly cooperative and good cooperation.
Together, we have been able to achieve a lot in the negotiations with the Member States.
As rapporteur of my group, I recommend that we agree to this report. Nevertheless, it could have been much better.
And with better, my esteemed colleagues, I mean safer.
For us Social Democrats, the safety of vehicles and thus the safety of drivers was always a priority, especially the safety of scooter riders and motorcyclists.
The number of injured motorcyclists has remained constant for years.
In general, the number of fatalities in Europe is decreasing, except for motorcycle accidents.
The reduction in the number of killed motorcyclists and scooter riders is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on European roads, that was and that is my goal.
Every dead person is one too many.
Especially in an ordinance so beneficial for the internal market, this issue must be intensively addressed.
I am still convinced that this can be done through effective technologies of anti-blocking systems, i.e. ABS.
Und von der Kosteneffektivität bin ich genauso überzeugt.
It is not true that ABS is too expensive.
We have achieved that from 2016 all new and from 2017 all existing motorcycle types with a displacement of 125 cubic centimeters or more from the manufacturer must be equipped with ABS.
With motor scooters, we could, from the manufacturers, can optionally be equipped with ABS or combined braking systems.
In this regard, we must unfortunately admit that we have not achieved any improvement on the Commission's proposal.
I would have liked much more here, but the Commission and Member States have shown themselves, to put it cautiously, to be very reluctant.
We have nevertheless achieved that in 2019 the Commission presents a report.
The report must be based on traffic accident data from the Member States and should examine the mandatory installation of ABS for motor vehicles.
Furthermore, it is sent to the Parliament and the Council.
On the basis of this report, the Commission should then consider making the installation of ABS mandatory.
You see, the topic remains very, very lively.
Therefore, we will try to close the binding gap in legislation from 2019.
I am sure that the data collected will be correct.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for the drivers of two-wheeled vehicles in Europe and that the number of accidents will decrease in the future. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President Matthias Grote. There is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
Und ich glaube, das gilt auch für das, was wir heute hier diskutieren.
I am very much in favor of us discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new access to the energy markets through unconventional resources, and that is both with gas, mainly with gas, but also with oil and.

I believe it is neither appropriate to fall into great euphoria, the great gas future. It is just as inappropriate as some of my colleagues from the Greens and Left have done here to paint large horror and fear scenarios on the wall that have nothing to do with reality at all.

I think that we have to keep in mind that these unconventional resources have the stuff to change all the energy supply relationships that we know of between suppliers and demanders, and that economic calculations of previous energy providers are also in question.
Der Entwicklung sollten wir uns stellen.

I think that we should take note that this can also be an opportunity for Europe and not just a risk. We should prepare ourselves to positively occupy and use new technologies, to balance opportunities and risks fairly, and not to fall into ideological debates. Thank you.
Mr. Commissioner, for your answer, you do not satisfy me completely.
Because I think it is a very, very long period of time, a year between the notification that the complaint has been received and possibly only so late to receive an answer.
I believe a complainant who makes the effort and usually has already gone through the entire legal process in his member state deserves more.
We are dependent on citizens to commit to the European Union.
If you do it in this forum, we should treat you accordingly.

And I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have a procedure here that is clearly formalized and that clearly regulates the rights. This is now a declaration of how the Commission wants to handle this.
On another point, I have nothing against it if it serves the purpose of trying to bring about a kind of mutual agreement with the member state.
Only that will not always be enough.
We observe that, for example, in economic matters, things move relatively quickly when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.

Aber wenn es zum Beispiel Umweltfragen geht und ähnliche Fragen, wo eben sehr, sehr viele Bürgerinnen und Bürger die Tätigkeit der Europäischen Union einfordern oder auch soziale Rechte, dann geht das schon etwas mühsamer vor sich.
I believe that these facts must also be taken into account.

And I wish for the next report that we have, so to speak, a clear formalization of the rights of the complainant vis-à-vis the Commission, which are also really clear and which are also really well communicated.
Once again, if we really want European law to be applied, after all the procedures we have had here in the European Parliament, in the Council.
Gemeinsam beschlossen haben, dann müssen wir jene, die sich darum kümmern, die sich wirklich sozusagen europäisch engagieren, so gut und so präzise wie möglich informieren.
This is a very, very big concern of mine.
Und ich werde es auch das nächste Mal wieder genau beobachten, was sich hier entwickelt hat. Danke.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, five years ago the EU Central Asia Strategy was launched.
If you ask for the balance sheet of this strategy today, the assessment is ambiguous.
We see how the Member States individually strive for good economic relations, especially with the resource-rich countries of this region, on the other hand, the efforts are not making any progress.
To accompany the states on their transformation process to modern democratic societies, or as the recent events in Kazakhstan show, the development is even marked by setbacks.

Nevertheless, or precisely because of this, the European Union and the Member States must express their influence in this region more strongly together, especially towards Kazakhstan, which has now become a major supplier for many EU countries.

An isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only lead to the influence of the co-applicant in this geopolitically important country, which the insistence on compliance with citizens' and human rights is not so important, being even stronger than before.
The linking of economic interests with the commitment to the protection of civil rights is the core of the Central Asia strategy.
This should also be the basis for further negotiations for a partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan.
The present report provides a good orientation for this. Thank you very much.
Ladies and gentlemen of the non-attendant council, perhaps you are following us on the Parliament's video stream, as you obviously have neither capacity nor desire to speak live with us.
I consider the absence of the Council here and today as a gross disrespect of Parliament.
Instead of pushing this debate, you should rather air your secret, which is why you are refusing to improve the protection of personal data in the field of police and justice through a directive.

Police and justice have been, as we know, an Eldorado of violations in the field of data protection for years, not only with SWIFT, but for example, in the daily collection and storage of data from citizens who, for example, demonstrate against Nazis, unlawfully.
We need the same protection standards for the public and private sector and for police and justice. This is what it is about, in order to be able to guarantee civil rights.
If the Council is required by Parliament to participate constructively in data protection regulations such as EU PNA or Europol, then the same must also apply to the Council in reverse.
Therefore, I demand that you finally put an end to the blockade policy in the field of data protection.
